entry.title: Re: SAP Enterprise Support renewal payment is done, but c...
entry.content:
Hello customer,

If your S-user has the authorization 'Manage Invoices and Payments' but you cannot see any invoice under the Billing tab in Finance & Legal dashboard, very possible that the invoice management is currently not available for the county where you are located.

Kindly refer to KBA https://me.sap.com/notes/3405010 to check the current available countries for invoice management.

All other users out side of the country list, please use SAP Biller Direct instead to view and pay their invoices. 

For any problems logging into SAP Biller Direct, users can email the responsible support team for assistance directly using the contact information provided for their respective region:

  • EMEA: billerdirect.emea@sap.com
  • LATAM: billerdirect.latam@sap.com
  • APJ: billerdirect.apj@sap.com
  • MEE: billerdirect.mee@sap.com

For any inquiries regarding missing invoices or information on paid invoices, it is advised to contact the relevant team by sending an email to the country-specific contract and their respective email addresses provided in the Attachments section of  KBA 3405010, titled AR Mailboxes Global version.pdf. Alternatively, reach out to the SAP Cash Collection Team by emailing FinanceAR@sap.com. 

Thanks for your attention.

Best regards,
SAP Support

entry.title: The Procurement Monthly - December & January
entry.content:
Summary. 1

State of Flux 2025 Global SRM Research Report. 1

McKinsey State of AI 2025. 2

Gartner. 2

RPA Relevance in the AI Era. 2

AI and Jobs Report. 3

Top AI Strategic Predictions 2026 and Beyond. 3

World CC Contract Management Benchmark 2025. 3

Sphera Geopolitical Disruption Survey. 4

Economist Impact- Enterprise AI blueprint. 4

MHI Top Supply Chain Trends. 5

ProcureTech100 Yearbook 2025/26 ‚Äì Art of Procurement & McKinsey. 5

Gartner - Predicts 2026: Procurement. 6

2026 Procurement Agenda and Key Issues Study ‚Äì The Hackett Group. 6

 

Summary

Several themes appear consistently this month. First, AI adoption is widespread but scaling remains elusive. Organizations experiment extensively yet struggle to achieve enterprise-level impact.

Second, internal barriers outweigh external challenges. Budget constraints, competing priorities, and organizational change block progress more than market volatility or geopolitical disruption.

Third, supplier relationships require fundamental reframing. Suppliers deliver customer experience, employ the workforce indirectly, and hold innovation potential. Treating them transactionally sacrifices competitive advantage.

Fourth, technology fragmentation undermines transformation. Excel dominates where purpose-built solutions should operate. Integration gaps prevent the visibility and automation organizations need.

Fifth, workforce impacts demand attention now. AI will transform millions of jobs annually. Organizations focusing on layoff announcements miss the larger challenge of redesigning roles and building capabilities.

State of Flux 2025 Global SRM Research Report

Supplier relationship management maturity continues to decline globally. Only 6% of organizations have mature supplier management capabilities, down from 8% in 2023. The research surveyed 484 respondents across 335 companies and reveals a concerning disconnect: CEOs spend just 1% of their time with suppliers despite suppliers delivering 50% of customer touchpoints and employing more than half the workforce indirectly.‚Äã

Organisations that achieve customer of choice status with suppliers gain priority access to innovation, better pricing, and improved service during disruptions. 90% of Leader organizations report suppliers bring their best people when the relationship is strong. 81% of Leaders engage in joint account planning, compared to only 17% of Followers.‚Äã

The primary barriers to SRM progress remain internal. Competing business priorities, organizational change, and budget constraints outweigh external challenges. Technology remains fragmented, with 87% of organizations relying on Excel or office tools to manage suppliers. Only 10% of Leaders have tools prioritizing value and innovation creation.‚Äã

The report argues procurement must reframe conversations from efficiency to enterprise value. Suppliers are brand ambassadors who directly influence customer experience. Treating them as transactional vendors undermines competitive advantage. Investment priorities should include purpose-built SRM technology, capability building for supplier-facing roles, and governance models embedding SRM into business rhythms.‚Äã

McKinsey State of AI 2025

According to the report, AI adoption is now nearly universal, with 88% of organizations using AI in at least one business function. Yet most remain stuck in experimentation. Only 32% have begun scaling AI across the enterprise. The gap between adoption and impact persists, with just 39% reporting EBIT impact at the enterprise level.‚Äã

AI agents have emerged as a significant focus area. 62% of respondents are experimenting with agents, and 23% are scaling agentic systems somewhere in the enterprise. Technology, media, telecommunications, and healthcare sectors lead agent adoption. IT, knowledge management, and software engineering functions show the highest scaling rates.‚Äã

High performers differentiate themselves through ambition. They are 3.6 times more likely to pursue transformative business change with AI, not just incremental efficiency. They redesign workflows fundamentally, achieving 2.8 times the rate of workflow transformation compared to peers. High performers invest over 20% of digital budgets in AI, compared to 10% for average organizations.‚Äã

Workforce impacts vary. 32% of respondents expect workforce decreases from AI in the next year, 43% expect no change, and 13% expect increases. Larger companies are more likely to anticipate workforce reductions. Each year, AI will significantly transform 32 million jobs, requiring upskilling or complete role redesign.‚Äã

Gartner

RPA Relevance in the AI Era

RPA remains the optimal solution for rule-based processes involving high volumes of structured data. AI and intelligent automation suit complex, dynamic, or unstructured tasks but require higher investment, strong data quality, and organizational readiness.‚Äã

The report maps specific RPA use cases across source-to-pay processes. Sourcing benefits from automated request monitoring via standardized email forms. Contract management gains from data cleansing and expiry monitoring. Supplier management improves through automated documentation requests and pricing updates. Procure-to-pay functions benefit from requisition validation, purchase order maintenance, and three-way matching automation.‚Äã

AI is enhancing RPA rather than replacing it. New capabilities include reduced bot development timelines, improved exception handling, and self-healing bots. Organizations should monitor RPA performance continuously and reassess automation strategies as AI matures. The recommendation is clear: use RPA for high-volume repetitive tasks delivering immediate gains while selectively deploying AI where it provides strategic value.‚Äã

AI and Jobs Report

AI will create more jobs than it eliminates beginning in 2028-2029. However, 32 million jobs will transform significantly each year. Daily, 150,000 jobs will evolve through upskilling while 70,000 will require complete redesign. Job transformation demands 20 times more organizational effort than layoffs or hiring.‚Äã

Industry impacts vary dramatically. Technology sector faces the most severe disruption but represents less than 2% of the global workforce. Asset-intensive industries show lower AI exposure due to physical work requirements. Services and public sectors will experience more job losses than gains due to weak adaptability despite high automation pressure.‚Äã

The analysis reveals critical nuances. Less than 1% of announced layoffs in early 2025 were attributable to AI productivity gains. 79% had no AI connection whatsoever. Acting on layoff hype will create strategic errors. Financial services and public sector organizations will face severe skills shortages as expectations outpace feasibility.‚Äã

Top AI Strategic Predictions 2026 and Beyond

By 2027, 75% of hiring processes will require AI proficiency testing. Half of GenAI performance gains depend on prompt quality. Job postings mentioning AI skills command 28% salary premiums. Organizations should integrate AI proficiency assessments into talent management immediately.‚Äã

Critical thinking skill atrophy will force 50% of organizations to require AI-free assessments through 2026. Overreliance on AI degrades inherent abilities. Staff beginning their careers face the highest risk, skipping validation steps that build cognitive capabilities.

By 2028, 90% of B2B buying will be AI-agent-intermediated, affecting over $15 trillion in spend. Multiagent AI systems will dominate customer-facing processes. Organizations must shift from optimizing for human persuasion to enabling autonomous agent interaction. Verifiable operational data becomes essential currency in this new ecosystem.‚Äã

World CC Contract Management Benchmark 2025

This years report identifies that 87% of organizations face high uncertainty levels, yet contracting capability remains neglected. 88% of executives acknowledge contract management excellence matters, but a massive gap separates recognition from action. Only 10% execute successfully on improvement plans while 50% struggle to formulate any response.‚Äã

48% of respondents acknowledge no clarity exists over who owns contracting process quality. Analysis reveals the true figure is 70-80%. Contract management suffers from superficial shared responsibility without genuine ownership. The report states that this governance failure undermines all other improvement efforts.‚Äã

Buy-side organizations operate with greater rigidity, processes designed for compliance rather than flexibility.

AI adoption accelerates. 40% of organizations use AI in approved forms, with 23% under review. High-performing organizations show 80% interest in AI and machine learning versus 57% for those with less integrated processes. The Global Contract Management Standard, launched June 2025, offers a framework for sustained improvement.‚Äã

Sphera Geopolitical Disruption Survey

A study of over 200 global CSCO and CPOs identified that 95% of CPOs and CSCOs express concern about geopolitical instability impacting supply chains in the next 12-24 months. 64% are very concerned. Macroeconomic volatility follows closely at 95.5% concern. Regulatory uncertainty affects 88.5%, and supplier financial health concerns 88%.‚Äã

Geopolitical tensions represent the single most disruptive risk for 35.5% of respondents, followed by macroeconomic instability at 24.5%. Organizations are responding with geographic supplier diversification (52.5% already implemented), nearshoring production (40% completed), and increased inventory buffers (55.5% in place).‚Äã

Barriers to resilience remain substantial. 55% cite supplier engagement challenges, 50% report budget constraints and ROI justification difficulties, 45% lack accurate supply chain data, and 39% have limited visibility beyond Tier 1 suppliers. Only 10% report no current barriers.‚Äã

Investment priorities for the next 12-18 months focus on tariff and trade uncertainty (27% of resources), geopolitical disruption (25%), regulatory compliance (23%), and climate-related risks (19%). Organizations relocating supply chains cite geopolitical instability (26%), tariffs (26%), macroeconomic volatility (18%), and regulatory uncertainty (15%) as primary drivers.‚Äã

Economist Impact- Enterprise AI blueprint

This article states that business leaders face a troubling disconnect. Executives from 57% of S&P 500 companies discussed AI during Q4 2025 earnings calls, yet only 10% of employees have used AI in recent weeks. Erik Brynjolfsson, director of the Digital Economy Lab at Stanford University, offers four critical recommendations for closing this gap.

Organizations must first acknowledge the productivity J-curve. AI requires substantial complementary investments in restructured workflows, employee skills and new processes. These supporting investments can significantly exceed actual AI technology spending. Returns will not appear immediately. Input costs surge before output materializes, creating temporary productivity declines. Brynjolfsson notes that electrification only delivered productivity gains after factories were redesigned around distributed motors, a transformation spanning nearly three decades. AI's J-curve may be shorter because the technology can sometimes address its own implementation challenges.

Brynjolfsson advises structuring work around tasks rather than job titles and using AI to amplify human judgment rather than replace it. The largest gains flow to organizations building centaur teams where humans and AI learn from one another and leaders measure results rigorously. One Stanford study of 5,172 customer support agents found AI assistance increased productivity by 15% on average, with largest improvements among less experienced workers who benefited from AI capturing best practices of top performers

MHI Top Supply Chain Trends

MHI has released its annual forecast of forces shaping supply chain operations. The 2026 report identifies nine critical priorities reflecting a shift from reactive fixes toward proactive preparation. These nine trends share a common thread. Successful supply chains require technology adoption, proactive risk management and cross-functional collaboration

The first trend is workforce and talent gap. AI and automation require tech-savvy professionals, prompting organizations to invest heavily in reskilling programs and workplace cultures that foster innovation. Talent shortages directly limit the pace at which companies can adopt new technologies.

Artificial intelligence and real-time data form the second priority. Generative AI and predictive analytics have moved from optional to essential. Companies use these tools for demand forecasting, supplier evaluation and real-time decision-making that improves customer service. AI-driven decision-making will become mainstream in 2026

Automation and emerging technology rank third. Robotics and automated systems build flexible operations that counter workforce shortages and sudden demand shifts. According to MHI data, 41% of supply chain organizations have already adopted robotics and automation, with another 42% planning adoption within five years

Trade and tariffs occupy the fourth position. Shifting geopolitics force companies to rethink sourcing through supplier diversification and reshoring work to reduce risk exposure.‚Äã

Uncertainty, inflation and rising costs represent the fifth trend. Economic volatility delays some deals while accelerating others as companies hedge against price increases.‚Äã

Cybersecurity and risk management rank sixth. Greater connectivity expands cyber threat exposure. Companies are building stronger cybersecurity frameworks and deepening supplier relationships to protect data collaboratively. Forbes survey data shows 38% of supply chain leaders perceive cyber threats as significant.‚Äã

E-commerce and inventory pressures come seventh. Customer expectations shifted rapidly. Inventory visibility, accurate forecasting, faster logistics and tighter quality control are now essential.‚Äã

Agility and resiliency form the eighth trend. Agile supply chains use technology to adjust quickly when challenges arise. Digital transformation, cross-team collaboration and detailed contingency planning anchor rapid recovery strategies.‚Äã

Environmental sustainability closes the list. Electric vehicles, route optimization and local fulfillment centres cut emissions and costs. However, AI's growing energy and water consumption creates tension with environmental goals.

ProcureTech100 Yearbook 2025/26 ‚Äì Art of Procurement & McKinsey

‚ÄãThe Yearbook is a practitioner‚Äëled benchmark for the 100 most impactful digital solutions reshaping procurement, rather than another pay‚Äëto‚Äëplay ranking. It highlights a market in rapid convergence, where category boundaries between sourcing, CLM, analytics, S2P, risk, sustainability and SRM are blurring into composable, AI‚Äëenabled ecosystems.

As part of the yearbook, there were a number of roundtables and some key trends emerged:

Category convergence and the rise of connected S2P stacks demand a deliberate architecture, not opportunistic tool buying. Tech strategies now need to define what is ‚Äúplatform‚Äù, what is ‚Äúspecialist‚Äù, and how data and workflows are orchestrated end‚Äëto‚Äëend.

‚Äã

‚ÄúReal‚Äëworld AI‚Äù and agentic systems shift the focus from experimentation to measurable outcomes ‚Äì productivity, risk, speed and experience ‚Äì with McKinsey suggesting potential 20x productivity uplift where agent factories are properly designed.

‚ÄãConnected intelligence and embedded analytics move insight from after‚Äëthe‚Äëfact reporting into the flow of work (sourcing, contracting, supplier discussions), making data quality and governance a board‚Äëlevel concern, not a clean‚Äëup exercise.

‚ÄãCLM is being reimagined around meaning and trust, with modular, AI‚Äëenabled tools for clause analysis, deviation detection and obligation tracking, changing how legal and procurement partner.

‚ÄãHuman‚Äëcentred procurement, hybrid operating models and orchestrated ecosystems underline that tech alone will not deliver; process design, skills, and operating model are now as strategic as category strategies

Gartner - Predicts 2026: Procurement

Five predictions emerged:

  • data/process maturity,
  • real‚Äëtime supplier evaluation,
  • multitier visibility,
  • AI‚Äëdriven roles, and
  • orchestration.

Through 2027, only about 20% of procurement organisations will have the data and process maturity to really exploit multi‚Äëagent systems ‚Äì and they will gain a clear competitive edge. Poor data quality, fragmented processes and legacy tech are identified as the primary drag on agentic AI, not algorithms.

‚ÄãBy 2028, 20% of teams are expected to use AI to continuously evaluate suppliers in real time, doubling coverage and extending metrics into collaboration, innovation and sustainability, using unstructured data from emails, chats and tickets.

By 2029, regulation and technology will push 40% of organisations to Tier‚Äë3 visibility, making supply‚Äëchain transparency a licence‚Äëto‚Äëoperate issue rather than a ‚Äúnice to have‚Äù.

Looking out to 2030, Gartner expects roughly 20% of procurement professionals to be in new AI‚Äëdriven roles, and AI to orchestrate procurement in 30% of organisations ‚Äì routing work between humans and agents based on strengths, context and risk.

2026 Procurement Agenda and Key Issues Study ‚Äì The Hackett Group

‚ÄãHackett‚Äôs 2026 study captures how senior procurement leaders are setting priorities in an uncertain macro environment.

‚ÄãThe 2026 ‚Äútop 10‚Äù is led by: ensuring supply continuity, improving spend cost reduction, deploying AI‚Äëenabled technology, and transforming the operating model. Digital transformation, third‚Äëparty risk visibility, agility, analytics and organisational velocity complete the list.

Workload is expected to rise by about 8% in 2026 while FTEs and operating budgets fall slightly, creating productivity and efficiency gaps of around 9% and 8% respectively ‚Äì gaps leaders clearly expect technology (with tech spend up c.6.1%) and AI to close.

‚ÄãSavings expectations have moderated: more organisations now expect flat purchase cost reduction and cost‚Äëavoidance performance versus 2025, even though a significant share still targets increases. The top value levers remain very traditional ‚Äì supplier negotiation, strategic sourcing, category management, contract review and demand management ‚Äì highlighting that AI is being layered onto, not replacing, core commercial disciplines.

‚ÄãTechnology adoption is already high across S2P suites, analytics, CLM and e‚Äësourcing, with further investment planned in spend analytics, CLM, e‚Äësourcing, advanced analytics and supplier performance management.

71% of respondents report some level of GenAI adoption and 56% for agentic AI (mostly in pilot stages), with strongest reported benefits in cycle‚Äëtime reduction, productivity and quality; value from FTE reduction and spend savings is emerging but less mature. Join me and Elizabeth Zucker for a webinar looking at these issues. Register here

 

As always reach out to discuss more, and always happy to hear your thoughts!

entry.title: Re: Stop Building From Scratch: Unlocking SAP Cloud Integration‚Äôs Standard Content
entry.content: It's Helpfull for me

entry.title: Re: Step-By-Step Guide: Creating Your First RAP Application using OData V4 and Transporting to Quali
entry.content:
That is exactly how it is done without any other systems involved like how @Mattias  uses it with gateway hub.

Rather straightforward process for this scenario to make a custom table available.
Once it becomes an unmanaged version or managed with unmanaged save it can become a bit more complicated.
This one is great to get first hands on with RAP.

Nice catch on the 'Do not publish from the service binding', this is correct and found that out the hard way.
When publishing from the service binding it cannot be transported and can be tricky to get it correct afterwards.
Always use /IWFND/V4_ADMIN for oDataV4 like @RajkumarGouda  mentioned, or the good old /IWFND/MAINT_SERVICE for oDataV2.

    • ‰∏≠ÂõΩÂ¢ûÂÄºÁ®éÂèëÁ•®ÁÆ°ÁêÜÊõ¥Êñ∞
    • ‰∏≠ÂõΩÁé∞ÈáëÊµÅÈáèË°®Êõ¥Êñ∞
    • ÁîµÂ≠êÂá≠ËØÅ‰ºöËÆ°Êï∞ÊçÆÊ†áÂáÜËß£ÂÜ≥ÊñπÊ°àÊõ¥Êñ∞
  • ‰∏≠ÂõΩÁé∞ÈáëÊµÅÈáèË°®ÔºàIDCNCASHÔºâÊóßÊñπÊ°àËø≠‰ª£Êõ¥Êñ∞

 

‰∏≠ÂõΩÂ¢ûÂÄºÁ®éÂèëÁ•®ÁÆ°ÁêÜ(Âü∫‰∫éSAP Document and Reporting Compliance)Êõ¥Êñ∞

ÈîÄÈ°πÂ¢ûÂÄºÁ®éÂèëÁ•®ÁÆ°ÁêÜÂäüËÉΩÊõ¥Êñ∞- SAPÈáëÁ®éÊé•Âè£ÔºàGTIÔºâÊñ∞Â¢ûÈÖçÁΩÆÔºöËÆ°Ë¥πÊäòÊâ£Á®é

Âú®Â§ßÂ§öÊï∞ÂÆ¢Êà∑Á≥ªÁªü‰∏≠ÔºåËÆ°Ë¥πÊäòÊâ£Á®é(Tax Discount AmountÔºåÁÆÄÁß∞TDA)ÈÄöÂ∏∏‰∏çÂú®SAPÈîÄÂîÆ‰∏éÂàÜÈîÄ(SD)Ê®°Âùó‰∏≠ËÆ°ÁÆó„ÄÇ‰∏∫‰∫ÜÂú®‰∏≠ÂõΩÂ¢ûÂÄºÁ®éÂèëÁ•®‰∏≠ÂáÜÁ°Æ‰ΩìÁé∞Ëøô‰∏ÄÈáëÈ¢ùÔºåSAPÈáëÁ®éÊé•Âè£(GTI)Âú®ËÆæËÆ°‰πãÂàùÈááÁî®‰∫ÜËá™Ë°åËÆ°ÁÆóÁöÑÊñπÂºè„ÄÇ

ÁÆÄËÄåË®Ä‰πãÔºåGTI‰∏ÄÁõ¥ÈááÁî®‰ª•‰∏ãÊñπÂºèËÆ°ÁÆóTDA:

  • ‰ªéSDËé∑Âèñ‰∏çÂê´Á®éÈ¢ù(Net Value)
  • Ëé∑ÂèñÁ®éÈ¢ù(Tax Amount)
  • Ëé∑ÂèñÊäòÊâ£ÈáëÈ¢ù(Discount Amount) 
  • Âú®GTI‰∏≠Áã¨Á´ãËÆ°ÁÆóÁ®éÊî∂ÊäòÊâ£ÈáëÈ¢ù(TDA)

Âú®Êüê‰∫õÁâπÊÆäÂú∫ÊôØ‰∏ãÔºå‰∏∫Á°Æ‰øùÊúÄÁªàÁ®éÈ¢ùÁöÑÂáÜÁ°ÆÊÄßÔºåGTI‰ºöË∞ÉÊï¥Âê´Á®éÊÄªÈ¢ù(Gross Amount)Ôºå‰ª•Á°Æ‰øùÂú®Êâ£Èô§ÊäòÊâ£ÂêéÁöÑÁ®éÈ¢ùÂú®ÈáëÁ®éÁ≥ªÁªüÂíåË¥¢Âä°‰∏≠ÊòØ‰∏ÄËá¥ÁöÑ„ÄÇËøôÂØºËá¥SAPÈîÄÂîÆËÆ¢Âçï‰∏éGTIÂºÄÂÖ∑ÂèëÁ•®‰∏äÁöÑÂê´Á®éÊÄªÈ¢ùÂá∫Áé∞Â∑ÆÂºÇÔºåÁªô‰∏öÂä°Áî®Êà∑ÁöÑÊó•Â∏∏Â∑•‰ΩúÂ∏¶Êù•Âõ∞Êâ∞„ÄÇ

‰ªéCE2602ÁâàÊú¨ÂºÄÂßãÔºåSAP GTIÊèê‰æõ‰∫ÜÊ†áÂáÜÈÖçÁΩÆÈÄâÈ°πÔºåÂÖÅËÆ∏Áî®Êà∑Áõ¥Êé•‰ªéSDÊ®°ÂùóËé∑ÂèñÁ®éÊî∂ÊäòÊâ£ÈáëÈ¢ùÔºåËÄåÈùûÂú®GTI‰∏≠ÈáçÊñ∞ËÆ°ÁÆó„ÄÇ

ÂÖ∑‰ΩìÊ≠•È™§Ôºö

  1. ‰ΩøÁî®Êñ∞Â¢ûÊ†áÂáÜÈÖçÁΩÆÈ°πÂÆö‰πâTDAÈáëÈ¢ùËÆæÁΩÆÔºöÁî®Êà∑Âú®ÈÖçÁΩÆ‚ÄúÈáëÁ®éÊµÅÁ®ãÁöÑÁº∫ÁúÅÂÄº‚Äù - ‚ÄúËÆ°Ë¥πÊäòÊâ£Á®é‚Äù‰∏≠ÔºåËæìÂÖ•Âú®SD‰∏≠ÂÆö‰πâÁöÑÊù°‰ª∂Á±ªÂûãCondition Type ID„ÄÇ

     Âõæ1ÔºöÊñ∞Â¢û‚ÄúËÆ°Ë¥πÊäòÊâ£Á®é‚ÄúÈáëÈ¢ùËÆæÁΩÆ

  2. ËÆæÁΩÆÊäòÊâ£ÈáëÈ¢ùÔºàDiscount AmountÔºâÂ±ûÊÄßÔºöÁî®Êà∑ËøòÈúÄÂú®Define GTI Tax Invoice KeysÂÜçÊ¨°Á°ÆËÆ§‚ÄòPrice Mode‚ÄôÈÖçÁΩÆÔºå‰ª•‰øùËØÅGTIËÆ°ÁÆóÊ≠£Á°ÆÔºö
    • Â¶ÇÊûúÂÆ¢Êà∑Âú®SD‰∏∫ÊäòÊâ£ÈáëÈ¢ùÁöÑÂÆö‰ª∑Êù°‰ª∂ËÆæÁΩÆÊòØÂê´Á®éÔºåÈÇ£‰πàÈáëÁ®é‰∏≠Price ModeÈúÄÈÄâÊã©‚ÄòDiscount Amount with VAT‚ÄôÔºõ
    • Â¶ÇÊûúÂÆ¢Êà∑Âú®SD‰∏∫ÊäòÊâ£ÈáëÈ¢ùÁöÑÂÆö‰ª∑Êù°‰ª∂ËÆæÁΩÆÊòØ‰∏çÂê´Á®éÔºåÈÇ£‰πàÈáëÁ®é‰∏≠Price ModeÈúÄÈÄâÊã©‚ÄòDiscount Amount without VAT‚ÄôÔºõ

ÈÄöËøáËøôÁßçÊñπÂºèÔºåËøô‰∏ÄÊîπËøõÊúâÊïàËß£ÂÜ≥‰∫ÜÊï∞ÊçÆ‰∏ç‰∏ÄËá¥ÁöÑÈóÆÈ¢òÔºåÂáèÂ∞ëÂõ†Á≥ªÁªüÂ∑ÆÂºÇÂØºËá¥ÁöÑ‰∏öÂä°Ê∑∑‰π±ÔºåËÆ©‰∏öÂä°ÊµÅÁ®ãÊõ¥Âä†È°∫ÁïÖ„ÄÇ

 

ÈîÄÈ°πÂ¢ûÂÄºÁ®éÂèëÁ•®ÁÆ°ÁêÜÂäüËÉΩÊõ¥Êñ∞ ‚Äì ‚ÄúÂ§áÊ≥®‚ÄùÂª∂ÈïøËá≥630‰∏™Â≠óÁ¨¶

Âú®ÂÖ≥‰∫éÂÖ®Èù¢Êï∞Â≠óÂåñÁîµÂ≠êÂèëÁ•®ÔºàFDEIÔºâ‰ΩøÁî®Â∏∏ËßÅÈóÆÈ¢òÊ∏ÖÂçïÁöÑÊõ¥Êñ∞ÂÖ¨Âëä‰∏≠ÔºåÊèêÂà∞‰∏ÄÈ°πÂèòÊõ¥Ê∂âÂèä ‚ÄúÂ§áÊ≥®‚ÄùÂ≠óÊÆµÁöÑÂ≠óÁ¨¶ÈïøÂ∫¶ÈôêÂà∂Ôºå‰∏ªË¶ÅÂèòÂåñÊòØ‰ªé‰πãÂâçÁöÑ230‰∏™Â≠óÁ¨¶Âª∂ÈïøËá≥630‰∏™Â≠óÁ¨¶„ÄÇÂêåÊó∂ÔºåÂ≠óÁ¨¶ËÆ°Êï∞ÊñπÊ≥ï‰πüËøõË°å‰∫ÜÊõ¥Êñ∞Ôºö‰∏Ä‰∏™Ê±âÂ≠óËÆ°‰∏∫‰∏â‰∏™Â≠óÁ¨¶ÔºåËÄåÊØè‰∏™Êï∞Â≠óÂíåËã±ÊñáÂ≠óÊØçËÆ°‰∏∫‰∏Ä‰∏™Â≠óÁ¨¶„ÄÇ

Âõæ2: ÊîØÊåÅÊ≠£Â∏∏ËØªÂÜôË∂ÖËøá230‰∏™Â≠óÁ¨¶ÁöÑÂ§áÊ≥®Â≠óÊÆµ

ËøôÊ¨°Ë∞ÉÊï¥ÊÑèÂë≥ÁùÄ‰ºÅ‰∏öÂú®ÂºÄÂÖ∑ÁîµÂ≠êÂèëÁ•®Êó∂ÔºåÂèØ‰ª•Âú®Â§áÊ≥®Ê†èÂ°´ÂÜôÊõ¥ËØ¶ÁªÜÁöÑ‰∫§Êòì‰ø°ÊÅØ„ÄÇ‰æãÂ¶ÇÔºåÂêàÂêåÁºñÂè∑„ÄÅÈ°πÁõÆÂêçÁß∞„ÄÅÁâπÊÆäËØ¥ÊòéÁ≠âÂÜÖÂÆπÈÉΩËÉΩÊõ¥ÂÆåÊï¥Âú∞ËÆ∞ÂΩïÔºåÂáèÂ∞ë‰∫ÜÂõ†Â≠óÊï∞ÈôêÂà∂ËÄåÈúÄË¶ÅÁÆÄÂåñÊèèËø∞ÁöÑÂõ∞Êâ∞„ÄÇ

‰ΩøÁî®FDEIÁöÑÁ∫≥Á®é‰∫∫ÔºåÂª∫ËÆÆÂæÅËØ¢ÂΩìÂú∞Á®éÂä°Êú∫ÂÖ≥Ëé∑ÂèñÊúÄÊñ∞ÁöÑFDEIÁöÑÂ∏∏ËßÅÈóÆÈ¢òÊ∏ÖÂçï„ÄÇ

Ê¨¢ËøéËÆøÈóÆSAP Regulatory Change Manager‰∫ÜËß£ËØ•Ê≥ïÂæãÂèòÊõ¥ÂèäSAP‰∫ßÂìÅÂäüËÉΩÂèòÊõ¥ÁöÑÊõ¥Â§ö‰ø°ÊÅØ„ÄÇ

 

ÈîÄÈ°πÂ¢ûÂÄºÁ®éÂèëÁ•®ÁÆ°ÁêÜÂäüËÉΩÊõ¥Êñ∞ ‚Äì ‚ÄúË°åÈ°πÁõÆÈôêÂà∂‚ÄùÊâ©Â±ïËá≥2000Ë°å

ÂºÄÂÖ∑ÂÖ®ÁîµÂèëÁ•®ÁöÑÊ®°Áâà‰∏≠ÔºåÂØπ‚ÄúÂèëÁ•®ÊòéÁªÜË°åÊï∞‚ÄúÁöÑÊúÄÊñ∞Ë¶ÅÊ±ÇÔºàÂ°´Ë°®ËØ¥ÊòéÔºâÊòØÔºöË∂ÖËøá2000Ë°åÂêéÂèØËÉΩ‰ºöÂØºËá¥Á≥ªÁªüÂºÇÂ∏∏Êó†Ê≥ïÂºÄÂÖ∑ÂèëÁ•®„ÄÇ

‰ªéCE2602Ëµ∑Ôºå‰ΩøÁî®‰∏≠ÂõΩÂ¢ûÂÄºÁ®éÂèëÁ•®ÁÆ°ÁêÜÊù•ÂºÄÂÖ∑ÂÖ®Èù¢Êï∞Â≠óÂåñÁîµÂ≠êÂèëÁ•®ÔºàFDEIÔºâÁöÑ‰ºÅ‰∏öÔºåÂèØ‰ª•Âú®Define GTI Tax Invoice Keys‰∏≠ÈÖçÁΩÆ‚ÄúË°åÈ°πÁõÆÈôêÂà∂‚Äù‰∏∫2000ÔºåÁ≥ªÁªü‰ºöËá™Âä®ÊãÜÂàÜË∂ÖËøá2000Ë°åÈôêÂà∂ÁöÑÁîµÂ≠êÂèëÁ•®„ÄÇ

Âõæ3: ËÆæÁΩÆË°åÈ°πÁõÆÈôêÂà∂‰∏∫2000

ÂºïÂÖ•Ëøô‰∏™Êñ∞ÈÖçÁΩÆÔºåÂèØ‰ΩøÁîüÊàêÁöÑÂèëÁ•®Êñá‰ª∂‰∏çË∂ÖËøáÁ®éÂ±ÄÊúçÂä°Âô®ÊâøËΩΩËÉΩÂäõÔºåÁ¨¶ÂêàÈôêÂà∂Ë¶ÅÊ±ÇÔºåÁ°Æ‰øùÁîüÊàêÁöÑÂèëÁ•®Êñá‰ª∂ÈÉΩËÉΩÊàêÂäü‰∏ä‰º†„ÄÇ

Ê¨¢ËøéËÆøÈóÆSAP Regulatory Change Manager‰∫ÜËß£ËØ•Ê≥ïÂæãÂèòÊõ¥ÂèäSAP‰∫ßÂìÅÂäüËÉΩÂèòÊõ¥ÁöÑÊõ¥Â§ö‰ø°ÊÅØ„ÄÇ

 

ËøõÈ°πÂ¢ûÂÄºÁ®éÂèëÁ•®ÁÆ°ÁêÜÂäüËÉΩÊõ¥Êñ∞ ‚Äì ÂèëÁ•®ÂÖ•Ë¥¶Ê†áËØÜ

entry.title: Unable to Delete Tax Code Rate Due to Posted Documents
entry.content:
Hello SAP Community,

In the Define Tax Codes for Sales and Purchases 101016 configuration, there is an existing tax rate maintained for Country CN with a rate of 6.72%, valid from 01/01/2021.

Recently, we maintained a new tax rate of 6%, valid from 01/20/2026, for the same tax code.

There are accounting documents posted using this tax code with a posting date of 01/20/2026.

Now, when we attempt to delete or remove this newly maintained tax rate, the system displays the following error message:

‚ÄúDocuments have been posted with Tax Code Z1 after valid-from date 01/20/2026.‚Äù

Due to this error, the system does not allow the deletion of the tax rate. We reversed the documents and tried but still the same error. Please suggest how to proceed further.

 

Thanks

Naveen Kumar

entry.title: Re: Tax determination in Third party sales order
entry.content:
SAP SD uses departure country (plant), destination country (ship-to), customer tax classification, and material tax classification. In third-party sales, the plant is often a dummy or not relevant, but SAP still expects it as the departure country. Simply adding vendor into a condition table won‚Äôt work because vendor data is not passed into the tax determination routine by default.

So, the recommended approach would be to use USEREXIT_PRICING_PREPARE_TKOMP to pass vendor country into tax determination, then rebuild your condition table with that field. This is the most reliable way to achieve vendor-based departure country logic in third-party sales.

entry.title: Re: Unable to Delete Tax Code Rate Due to Posted Documents
entry.content:
You cannot physically delete or remove the tax rate once documents have been posted with it, even if reversed. This is by design to ensure tax audit integrity. You cannot overwrite the rate directly in the same validity interval.

So the recommended approach would be instead of removing it, maintain a new validity interval. For example:

  • Keep the 6% rate valid from 20.01.2026.
  • Add another entry with 6.72% (or whatever rate is correct) valid from 21.01.2026 onward.

Create a new tax code: If the 6% rate was entered by mistake and should never be used again, define a new tax code with the correct rate and validity. Then use this new tax code in future postings.

Block the incorrect tax code: You can mark the tax code as ‚Äúinactive‚Äù in configuration so that users cannot select it going forward.

entry.title: Re: SAC Data Action: DELETE() with IF condition not working
entry.content:
Hi @AmirL 

The issue you are facing is related to the behavior of Dimension member comparison in Advanced Formulas. When you define the MEMBERSET using the "All" node or "Parent member ID" of the hierarchy, Advanced Formulas may produce results that differ from what you expect.
 
To obtain the desired results when using a MEMBERSET defined with the "All" node or a "Parent member ID" of the hierarchy, you can modify the script as follows.
  • IF [d/DIMENSION_MATERIAL] !== [d/DIMENSION_TECHNICAL_KEY].[p/Material] THEN
       DELETE()
    ENDIF
For more details on the behavior of dimension member comparison, please refer to the following SAP Blog.
  • The behavior of dimension member comparison in Advanced Formulas

 

I hope this is helpful to you, and if I have misunderstood anything, please feel free to reach out.

Moonjun

entry.title: Re: Email verification for provisioned users - IAS
entry.content:
@tskwin 

Below is the transformation for sending email .. By default is set to false (email won't be sent) and if you turn to true.. email goes... 

for Email verified flag .. you can set to verified using true but when you send the email, it automatically it turns to verified or non-verified.. so that you know they haven't verified yet nor logged in yet.

      {
        "constant": false,
        "targetPath": "$['urn:ietf:params:scim:schemas:extension:sap:2.0:User']['sendMail']",
        "scope": "createEntity"
      },
      {
        "constant": true,
        "targetPath": "$['urn:ietf:params:scim:schemas:extension:sap:2.0:User']['mailVerified']",
        "scope": "createEntity"
      },

entry.title: Developing AI Enabled Applications with ABAP AI SDK powered by ISLM
entry.content:
SAP Joule for Developers, ABAP AI Capabilities is your intelligent coding companion, bringing deep expertise in ABAP Cloud and AI-driven development. When we talk about ABAP AI use cases, they revolve around three key pillars ‚Äî Accelerate, Empower, and Transform. Each AI capability is delivered as part of these pillars, helping developers enhance productivity, build smarter applications, and drive innovation. To learn more about SAP Joule for Developers, refer to the blog post Joule speaks ABAP! by Dr. Alexander Rother.

Have you ever wondered how to infuse intelligence into your ABAP-based business applications and move beyond standard transactional scenarios? If yes, you‚Äôve landed at the right place. In this blog, we‚Äôll explore how you can build AI-enabled applications using the ABAP AI SDK powered by Intelligent Scenario Lifecycle Management (ISLM), the main deliverable of the Empower use case.

The Scenario 
The goal of this scenario is to infuse generative AI into an ABAP Cloud application to enhance user experience and automate content creation. 

Use Case: Build an ABAP Cloud application to generate a travel itinerary for a given city based on user input, along with a budget breakdown, using ABAP AI SDK powered by ISLM. 

Which products are supported? 

The ABAP AI SDK powered by ISLM is available in: 

  • SAP BTP ABAP Environment  
  • SAP S/4HANA Cloud Public Edition  
  • SAP S/4HANA Cloud Private Edition and SAP S/4HANA OnPrem as of release 2025 via standard delivery. Lower releases of SAP S/4HANA Cloud Private Edition and SAP S/4HANA OnPrem are supported via Transport-based Correction Instructions (TCI), see details in SAP Note 3513374 and the SAP Notes and instructions linked therein. 

Overview 

To build this application, we‚Äôll bring together several key components: 

  • SAP AI Core ‚Äì for managing AI scenarios and accessing generative AI capabilities via the generative AI hub. 
  • Communication Arrangement ‚Äì to establish secure integration between ABAP and AI Core. 
  • ISLM (Intelligent Scenario Lifecycle Management) and ABAP AI SDK ‚Äì for seamless integration with Generative AI Hub, SAP BTP AI services 
  • Custom ABAP Cloud Application ‚Äì to embed and expose AI capabilities through a user-friendly application. 

 Implementation Steps 

  1. Set Up the Environment 
    Configure the AI Core service plan and establish communication arrangements between the ABAP system and AI Core.
  2. Build Custom Travel Plan ABAP Cloud application. 
  3. Create and Deploy Intelligent Scenarios 
    Define the AI scenario in ISLM, train or connect your model, and deploy it for consumption. 
  4. Consume Intelligent Scenarios in ABAP 
    Integrate the deployed scenario within a custom ABAP Cloud application to generate AI-driven outputs - in this case, travel itineraries and budget breakdown. 

1. Set Up the Environment  

  1. Configure the required entitlements to make SAP AI Core accessible in your subaccount. To use Generative AI capabilities (including the Generative AI Hub and LLM access), choose the extended service plan. To add a Service Plan, see : Add a Service Plan | SAP Help Portal 
     
  2. Download the client default certificate of the ABAP system to create the X.509 service key in AI Core instance. Follow the steps here : Download Certificate | SAP Help Portal 
     
  3. Create a service instance and service key for accessing SAP AI Core, where the large language models in the generative AI hub are hosted. The X.509 service key is created with the downloaded client default certificate of the ABAP system passed as parameter. Follow the steps from here: Create SAP BTP Service Instance and Key | SAP Help Portal

  4. Configure communication system for SAP_COM_0A69. Currently, you can create one instance of the communication scenario per client. Follow the steps from here: How to Configure the Communication System for SAP_COM_0A69 | SAP Help Portal
     
  5. To create the Communication Arrangement for SAP_COM_0A69. Follow the steps from here: How to Create the Communication Arrangement for SAP_COM_0A69 | SAP Help Portal 

  6. After the communication system and communication arrangement are configured, create an intelligent scenario and continue managing the lifecycle of the intelligent scenario. You are required to create an intelligent scenario for your custom owned Gen AI use cases. 

2. Create a custom ABAP Cloud Application to infuse AI Capabilities 

2.1 Create Package

  1. In ADT, go to the Project Explorer, right-click on the package ZLOCAL, and select New > ABAP Package from the context menu.
  2. Maintain the required information: 
    1. Name: ZTRAVEL_ITINERARY
    2. Description: ABAP AI Capabilities
      Select the box Add to favorites package. Click Next and Finish.

 2.2 Create database table 

Create a database table to store the Travel Itinerary data.

  1. Right-click on your ABAP package ZTRAVEL_ITINERARY and select New > Other ABAP Repository Object from the context menu.
  2. Search for database table, select it, and click Next.
  3. Maintain the required information: Name: ZRAP_TRAVEL_DATA   Description: Database Table for Travel Itinerary
  4. Click Next. Click Finish and Replace the default code with the code snippet provided below 

 

@EndUserText.label : 'Database table for travel Itinerary'
@AbapCatalog.enhancement.category : #NOT_EXTENSIBLE
@AbapCatalog.tableCategory : #TRANSPARENT
@AbapCatalog.deliveryClass : #A
@AbapCatalog.dataMaintenance : #RESTRICTED
define table zrap_travel_data {
  key client            : abap.clnt not null;
  key travel_id         : sysuuid_x16 not null;
  traveler_name         : abap.char(80);
  starting_point        : abap.char(100);
  destination           : abap.char(100);
  start_date            : /dmo/begin_date;
  end_date              : /dmo/end_date;
  @Semantics.amount.currencyCode : 'zrap_travel_data.budget_curr'
  budget                : abap.curr(15,2);
  budget_curr           : abap.cuky;
  transport_mode        : abap.char(40);
  accommodation_type    : abap.char(50);
  ai_itinerary          : abap.sstring(1333);
  ai_budget_breakdown   : abap.sstring(1000);
  status                : abap.char(20);
  local_created_by      : abp_creation_user;
  local_created_at      : abp_creation_tstmpl;
  local_last_changed_by : abp_locinst_lastchange_user;
  local_last_changed_at : abp_locinst_lastchange_tstmpl;
  last_changed_at       : abp_lastchange_tstmpl;
}

        5. Save and activate the changes in the table ZRAP_TRAVEL_DATA

2.3 Generate transactional UI service

Create your OData v4 based UI service with the built-in ADT generator. The generated business service will be transactional, draft-enabled, and enriched with UI semantics for the generation of the Fiori elements app.

  1. Right-click your database table ZRAP_TRAVEL_DATA and select Generate ABAP Repository Objects from the context menu.


  2. Select OData UI Service and click Next and provide the package details.

     

  3.  Maintain the required information on the Configure Generator dialog to provide the name of your data model and generate them.
  4. For that, navigate through the wizard tree (Business Objects, Data Model, etc‚Ä¶), maintain the artefact names provided and press Next.
  5. Verify the maintained entries and press Next to confirm. Click on Finish.


  6. The artifacts needed will be generated. Go to the Project Explorer, select your package ZRAP_TRAVEL_ITENERARY, refresh it by pressing F5, and check all generated ABAP repository objects.



    ‚ÑπÔ∏èNOTE: The names of the artifacts may differ from those shown in this Blog, as they are generated by the wizard.

2.4 Adjust meta data extensions
Open the metadata extension ZC_RAP_TRAVEL_DATA and make the adjustments as shown in the code snippet below ZC_RAP_TRAVEL_DATA should look like this:

 2.5 Preview travel app

1. Publish the local service endpoint of your service binding and start the Fiori elements App Preview. Open your service binding ZUI_RAP_TRAVEL_DATA_O4 and click Publish.

2. Double-click on the Entity ZC_RAP_TRAVEL_DATA in the Entity Set and Association section to open the Fiori elements App Preview.

For Reference  : Create Database Table and Generate UI Service | SAP Tutorials

3. Create an Intelligent Scenario (Generative AI) 
 

You first need to create an intelligent scenario for your custom Generative AI use cases. This scenario acts as the central place to manage the entire lifecycle of your AI asset from setup to generating inference results. All lifecycle steps can be executed through the Intelligent Scenario Management app.Below are the key steps to create an intelligent scenario: 

3.1 Create ISLM Scenario

An intelligent scenario is an ABAP representation of a predictive business-specific use case. These intelligent scenarios are AI-powered workflows or processes designed to automate and optimize business tasks.  

  1. Select your package, right-click, New ‚Üí Other ‚Üí Intelligent Scenario ‚Üí ZINTS_RAP120


  2. Enter a name and description. Select SIDEBYSIDE for Scenario Technology field. Press Next


  3. Set the following parameters to the created Intelligent Scenario

Intelligent Scenario Lifecycle Management supports two primary types of intelligent scenarios:

Embedded Scenarios

Embedded scenarios are built and executed within SAP S/4HANA using the ABAP platform. They rely on the in-database machine learning capabilities of SAP HANA, such as: HANA Predictive Analysis Library (PAL),Automated Predictive Library (APL)

Side-by-Side Scenarios

Side-by-side scenarios, where SAP S/4HANA runs in a separate stack than its machine learning infrastructure provider, such as SAP Business Technology Platform (SAP BTP). These scenarios use external ML services or custom ML models.
Generative AI,SAP AI Core,Data Attribute Recommendation

  • For our scenario we will be using the side by side scenarios type, sap SAPGEN AI
    Turnkey Enablement: Automatically enable SAP-delivered (turnkey) GenAI use cases with minimal configuration effort.

 

Field

Value

Intelligent Scenario Type

SAPGENAI

Automate Turnkey Switch On

Check the checkbox

Usage Type

CUSTOMER

 

  1. Activate the object.

3.2 Create ISLM Model
1. Select your package, right-click, New ‚Üí Other ‚Üí Intelligent Scenario Model

2. Fill the Description and Model Name fields. Assign the previous created scenario in Intelligent Scenario Name. Click on Next 


3. Enter the ExecutableID and Large Language Model Name and Large Language Model Version

 

Field

Possible values

Executable Id

o        aicore-sap

o        aws-bedrock

o        azure-openai

o        gcp-vertexai

Large Language Model Name

It depends on the Executable Id

Large Language Model Version

One option is to leave the version field free, then the latest version will be used. This helps to avoid issues in case that the model has been deprecated in AI Core
 More info. https://me.sap.com/notes/3437766

 

 4. Through the Prompt Library API, we can use predefined prompt templates to generate new prompts. Currently prompt templates are defined through ISLM. In order to get an instance of the prompt template you want to use, you need to provide the ISLM scenario and the ID of the prompt template.Click on Add and provide the following Details. 
Prompt Template Name: SYSTEM_PROMPT_ITIN 
Prompt Template:System prompt for generating Itinerary 
Prompt: You are a professional travel planner. Create a {ISLM_days} day itinerary for a given destination, including daily highlights, must-visit spots and activities. Keep it under 1000 characters. 
 

 

 5. The prompt Parameters is captured from the prompt template after activation. 

 

6. Add another prompt template for User prompt. 
Prompt Template Name: USER_PROMPT_ITIN 
Prompt Template:User prompt template 
Prompt: Destination: {ISLM_destination} Departure: {ISLM_startingpoint} Travel Dates: {ISLM_startdate} to {ISLM_enddate}  Mode of Transport: {ISLM_transportmode} Accommodation Type: {ISLM_accommodationtype} Generate the itinerary now 
  
 

7. Activate the object
WARNING : Before you try the ABAP AI SDK out in an ABAP Class, please make sure that the deployment is running  

3.3 In Fiori Launchpad

To use the Intelligent Scenarios and Intelligent Scenario Management apps, you must have the appropriate access rights to the SAP Fiori Launchpad. The access for ISLM is added to the business role of an analytics specialist; BR_ANALYTICS_SPECIALIST.
 You can create and manage ISLM Scenarios through Intelligent Scenario Management app.

You can check your previously created scenario in the Intelligent Scenario Management Fiori App.
In the next step Instantiate ABAP AI SDK using the created ISLM Scenario 

3.4. Consume Intelligent Scenarios in ABAP

ABAP AI SDK
The ABAP AI SDK powered by Intelligent Scenario Lifecycle Management (ISLM) is an ABAP reuse library that supports you in interacting with large language models (LLMs) hosted on the generative AI hub in SAP AI Core. Using the ABAP AI SDK, you can build your own AI-based features in ABAP.

Completion API
This API provides access to the completion API functionality of Large Language Models (LLMs), meaning that it uses an LLM to generate a text response from a prompt.

Prompt Library API
Using the prompt library API, you can use prompt templates predefined via ISLM to generate new prompts.

Catchable Exceptions
The execution of the completion API may cause an error and therefore CX_AIC_COMPLETION_API can be caught as a result. When the error is triggered by the LLM itself or by the AI service provider, CX_AIC_COMPLETION_API provides further information about the error.

Add a determination to the Travel Business Object and enhance it with the ABAP AI SDK powered by ISLM. Define the determination generateAIItinerary in the behavior definition ZR_RAP_TRAVEL_DATA and implement it in the behavior implementation class, aka behavior pool ZBP_R_RAP_TRAVEL_DATA.

1.Add the mandatory fields. Go to the Project Explorer and open your behaviour definition ZR_RAP_TRAVEL_DATA.

field ( readonly )
TravelID,
Status,
AiBudgetBreakdown,
AiItinerary,
LocalCreatedBy,
LocalCreatedAt,
LocalLastChangedBy,
LocalLastChangedAt,
LastChangedAt;

field ( mandatory : create )
TravelerName,
EndDate,
StartDate,
Budget,
AccommodationType,
StartingPoint,
TransportMode,
Destination;

determination generateAIItinerary on modify { create; }

  Define the generateAIItinerary determination:

  1. Save and activate the changes in ZR_RAP_TRAVEL_DATA.
  2. Declare the required method in behavior implementation class ZBP_RAP_TRAVEL_DATA using ADT Quick Fix  Ctrl/Cmd + 1.

     

     

  3. Save and activate the changes in ZBP_R_RAP_TRAVEL_DATA.
  4. Let's implement the determination generateAIItinerary. In your implementation class ZBP_R_RAP_TRAVEL_DATA, In generateAIItinerary method implementation.
  5. Replace the following code. Your code should look like this:

 METHOD generateAIItinerary.
    LOOP AT keys INTO DATA(ls_key).
      READ ENTITIES OF zr_rap_travel_data IN LOCAL MODE
      ENTITY ZrRapTravelData
      FIELDS ( destination startdate enddate transportmode accommodationtype     BudgetCurr ) WITH CORRESPONDING #( keys )
      RESULT DATA(lt_travel).
      LOOP AT lt_travel INTO DATA(ls_travel).
        DATA(days) = ls_travel-enddate - ls_travel-startdate + 1.
        DATA(itinerary) = ``.
        DATA(budget)    = ``.
        IF ls_travel-AiItinerary IS INITIAL OR ls_travel-AiBudgetBreakdown IS INITIAL.
          TRY.

*Calling the Prompt Library API.Through the Prompt Library API, we can use predefined prompt templates to generate new prompts.

              FINAL(sys_prompt_template_instance) =  cl_aic_islm_prompt_tpl_factory=>get( )->create_instance(
                                                   islm_scenario = 'ZINTS_RAP120' template_id = 'SYSTEM_PROMPT_ITIN' ).
              " Add a system prompt based on an ISLM prompt template with one parameter
              FINAL(sys_prompt) = sys_prompt_template_instance->get_prompt( parameters = VALUE #( ( name  = 'ISLM_days'    value = days  ) ) ).

              " Add a user prompt based on an ISLM prompt template with parameters
              FINAL(user_prompt_template_instance) =  cl_aic_islm_prompt_tpl_factory=>get( )->create_instance(
                                                  islm_scenario = 'ZINTS_RAP120' template_id = 'USER_PROMPT_ITIN' ).

              FINAL(user_prompt) = user_prompt_template_instance->get_prompt( parameters = VALUE #(
     ( name  = 'ISLM_startdate'
       value =  |{ ls_travel-startdate }| )
     ( name  = 'ISLM_enddate'
       value = |{ ls_travel-enddate }| )
         ( name  = 'ISLM_startingpoint'
       value = ls_travel-StartingPoint )
           ( name  = 'ISLM_destination'
       value = ls_travel-Destination )
     ( name  = 'ISLM_transportmode'
       value = ls_travel-transportMode )
        ( name  = 'ISLM_accommodationtype'
       value = ls_travel-accommodationtype )
   ) ) .




              FINAL(api_itin) = cl_aic_islm_compl_api_factory=>get( )->create_instance(
                                                      islm_scenario = 'ZINTS_RAP120' ).

*Set the LLM parameters
              FINAL(params) = api_itin->get_parameter_setter( ).
              params->set_maximum_tokens( 800 ).


              FINAL(msg_itin) = api_itin->create_message_container( ).
              msg_itin->set_system_role( sys_prompt ).
              msg_itin->add_user_message( user_prompt ).
              itinerary = api_itin->execute_for_messages( msg_itin )->get_completion( ).
            CATCH cx_aic_api_factory INTO DATA(lx_api_itin).
              itinerary = |AI instance creation failed for itinerary.|.
            CATCH cx_aic_completion_api INTO DATA(lx_comp_itin).
              itinerary = |AI completion call failed for itinerary.|.
          ENDTRY.
          IF itinerary IS NOT INITIAL.
            TRY.

* To pass prompts directly without prompt parameters
* Your ISLM scenario for itinerary

                DATA(system_prompt_budget) =
                  |You are a travel finance advisor. Based on the Itenary , destination, duration, | &&
                  |and total budget, estimate how much to allocate for travel, hotel, | &&
                  |food, sightseeing, and miscellaneous expenses. Output under 500 characters.|.
                DATA(user_prompt_budget) =
                  |Itenerary: { itinerary }| &&
                  |Departure: { ls_travel-StartingPoint }| &&
                 |Destination: { ls_travel-destination }| &&
                  |\nTravel Dates: { ls_travel-startdate } to { ls_travel-enddate }| &&
                  |\nTotal Budget: ‚Çπ{ ls_travel-Budget }| &&
                  |\nTotal Budget Currency: ‚Çπ{ ls_travel-BudgetCurr }| &&
                  |\nProvide a short, realistic breakdown.|.
                FINAL(api_budget) = cl_aic_islm_compl_api_factory=>get( )->create_instance(
                                                      islm_scenario = 'ZINTS_RAP120' ).
                " Your ISLM scenario for budget
                FINAL(msg_budget) = api_budget->create_message_container( ).
                msg_budget->set_system_role( system_prompt_budget ).
                msg_budget->add_user_message( user_prompt_budget ).
                budget = api_budget->execute_for_messages( msg_budget )->get_completion( ).
              CATCH cx_aic_api_factory INTO DATA(lx_api_budget).
                budget = |AI instance creation failed for budget.|.
              CATCH cx_aic_completion_api INTO DATA(lx_comp_budget).
                budget = |AI completion call failed for budget.|.
            ENDTRY.
          ENDIF.
          MODIFY ENTITIES OF zr_rap_travel_data  IN LOCAL MODE
            ENTITY ZrRapTravelData
           UPDATE FIELDS ( aiitinerary aibudgetbreakdown status )
            WITH VALUE #(
              ( %tky = ls_travel-%tky
                aiitinerary        = itinerary
                aibudgetbreakdown = budget
                status              = 'Generated' )
            ).
        ENDIF.
      ENDLOOP.
    ENDLOOP.

  ENDMETHOD.
  1. Save and activate the changes in ZBP_R_RAP_TRAVEL_DATA.
  2. Preview and test the enhanced Travel Itinerary App with Generative AI Capabilities.

entry.title: Re: Migration Manager Protection is disabled and you are...
entry.content:
Hi VictorG_inycom,

There is internal setting which controls if Migration Manager works with protected files or not. This settings is not available to admins from the Setup, that is why you don't see it and you can't find documentation about it. This protection is added from the security reasons some time ago. But unfortunately it seems that it was not turned on for all tenants. 

If it happens that one tenant is having this turned on and the other is not, then that message is displayed. To resolve your situation, you need to raise a Support ticket and tell them which tenants are you working with, and they will turn on protection on all of them, so you can continue to migrate freely between them. 

We will investigate the situation and plan for future to have this settings on for all tenants on all environments to avoid others running into the same problem.

 

Best regards

  Lana Nikolic-Cvijic 

(Product Manager of Advanced Workflow)

entry.title: Period and volume discount not seen in sap customer checkout sales screen
entry.content:
Hello dear community members,

I have configured a period and volume discount in SAP Business One with a 15% discount for an item (ItemCode 109, original price 3300).

However, in SAP Customer Checkout, the item is displayed with the discounted price already applied (price shown as 2805). Because of this, cashiers cannot see the applied discount and cannot explain to customers that the original price is 3300 and the discounted price is 2805.

Is it possible to display the discount amount or percentage in the Discount column in SAP Customer Checkout? In SAP Business One it shows as expected, discount percent is another column.
Currently, the Discount column shows 0.

 

Thank you in advance for your support

SAP Customer Checkout @bikash_bansal @gunther_sandtner

entry.title: Re: How to use Custom Logic App to pass Contract Header d...
entry.content:
Hi @bigflatfoot ,

For the data transfer between Contract and Order I would recommend to use the BAdIs in Copying Control (SD_SLS_DATA_TRANSFER_HEAD). You can find all the details here in the documentation.

The BAdI SD_SLS_MODIFY_HEAD is called multiple times during sales document processing which means also if you do any changes to the order, the BAdI will be executed again which is not needed in your case I think. If the interface of the BadI does not provide all the fields you need, please create a feature request via influence portal.

best regards,
Christian

entry.title: Re: A simplified approach to choosing between S/4HANA Public vs Private Cloud
entry.content:
A crucial point to consider is an exit strategy - how are you going to get your data back when you get fed up with the cloud?

Even if there are no standard exit tools, custom data extractors can be build in Private Cloud. So there is a way out of the Private Cloud. Is there any out of Public one?

entry.title: Re: Purchase order accruals POAC and periodic billing plan
entry.content:
Hello Lakshmipathi

Thank you very much for this clear and detailled answer.

About the possibilities you give allow me to give a feedback for my own case (indeed all what you are suggesting would work) :

Split PO items by period
The use of a periodic billing in our company is also to make procurement work easier so I don't think business would accept to split a PO line into several

Use Service Entry Sheets (SES)
My company is already using SES (and no direct GR as we are buying almost only services and no goods). It works very well however it is very hard for us in term to get the requestor approve the SES. So invoicing plan was used as an alternative to SES

Custom enhancement (BAdI / substitution)
Indeed the may be the most relevant solution for us. as we are in Private Cloud

Alternative reporting
Thanks for this idea too that may suit our needs (even if it would add manual steps, it doesn't involve any custom abap development)

To sum up all what you are suggesting would work but option 3 and 4 are the most relevant for us.

So thank very much again for taking the time to answer and the high quality of your answer üôÇ

Best regards

Thibaut

entry.title: AI in SAP SuccessFactors (2026) ‚Äî The Adoption Operating Model
entry.content:
Part 3 of the ‚ÄúPractical Implementation Blueprint‚Äù series

Goal of this blog: Help you run AI in SuccessFactors like a product you operate, not a feature you enable once, so adoption stays trusted, measurable, and release-aligned.

Continuation from Part 1 & Part 2

In Part 1, we covered readiness, governance, identity/permissions, and the activation roadmap across Joule, embedded AI, and extensibility. In Part 2, we focused on the change blueprint: leadership ownership, frontline manager enablement, and operationalizing ‚ÄúAI suggests; humans decide‚Äù.

Now Part 3 answers what customers hit after go-live:
How do we run AI like a product -- safely, predictably, and aligned to SAP releases : without chaos, adoption drop-off, or budget surprises?

Series navigation: If you‚Äôre just starting with this blog, I recommend reading the first two posts first, then continuing here with Part 3.

  • Part 1 ‚Äî AI in SAP SuccessFactors (2026): The Practical Implementation Blueprint
  • Part 2 ‚Äî AI in SAP SuccessFactors (2026): The Change Management Blueprint
  • Part 3 ‚Äî AI in SAP SuccessFactors (2026): The Adoption Operating Model (this blog) üòä

Executive Summary (2-minute read)

The challenge: Many AI initiatives fail to scale because operating ownership, risk controls, and value tracking aren‚Äôt designed for continuous AI change. Gartner has predicted that a significant portion of agentic AI projects will be cancelled due to cost, unclear value, or insufficient risk controls.

The solution: Treat AI as a product you operate, not a feature you ‚Äúturn on once.‚Äù

What you'll get

  • A minimum viable COE with clear accountability (and practical time allocations)
  • A three-tier governance cadence that stays agile without losing control
  • A single intake model that stops ‚Äúrandom cool ideas‚Äù
  • A release-aligned quality loop so accuracy doesn‚Äôt erode over time
  • AI Units governance patterns using SAP usage metrics + dashboards
  • EU AI Act‚Äìaligned literacy + employment-risk handling patterns

Time to value (practical guidance)

  • 4‚Äì8 weeks to stand up basic governance + intake + dashboards
  • 3‚Äì6 months to stabilize the quality loop and embed monthly steering rhythms
  • 6‚Äì12 months to reach predictable ‚Äúproduct mode‚Äù cadence aligned to releases

0) Why an operating model is required in 2026

AI in SuccessFactors is not static. You‚Äôre operating in a world of:

  • Joule capabilities evolving and relying on correct setup and permissions (for example, ‚ÄúAccess to Joule‚Äù prerequisites).
  • Premium AI consumption monitoring through AI Units usage metrics and dashboards.
  • EU AI Act obligations, including AI literacy measures (Article 4 + EU Q&A).
  • Employment-related risk handling, because employment/worker management use cases are explicitly highlighted under Annex III (recruitment/selection and worker-management contexts).

That‚Äôs why mature customers shift from ‚ÄúAI rollout project‚Äù to an ‚ÄúAI product operating model.‚Äù

The 5 most common failure patterns (and how this blog prevents them)

Failure pattern
What happensPrevention strategy (where in this blog)
1) Orphaned ownership‚ÄúEveryone owns AI‚Äù = no one owns it. Backlog becomes political. Adoption becomes inconsistent.Section 2 (COE roles + time allocation), Section 3 (cadence + decision rights)
2) Permission driftRBP/security changes break Joule journeys; users perceive ‚ÄúAI is broken.‚ÄùSection 1.2, Section 5 (RBP impact checks + regression)
3) Random innovationMany custom skills/agents get built without lifecycle, test, support, or retirement plan.Section 4 (single intake + scorecard + decision tree)
4) Budget shockConsumption spikes appear when scaling cohorts or launching high-usage scenarios.Section 7 (monthly governance + spike diagnostic)
5) Quality erosionAccuracy and usefulness degrade release-over-release; no one notices until trust collapses.Section 6 (weekly quality loop + classification + fixes)

1) Operating model principles (2026 rules of the road)

1.1 One program, three AI surfaces

AI shows up in three interconnected layers:

  • Joule (assistant experience and guided support)
  • Embedded AI (AI-assisted experiences inside modules)
  • Extensibility (Joule Studio / SAP Build) for custom agents and integrations

Operating model implication: One intake, one backlog, one cadence, one measurement framework.

Illustrative example (common pattern): Organizations that consolidate Joule, embedded AI, and custom skills under one Product Owner and one backlog typically reduce duplicated initiatives and clarify the ‚Äúwhich AI to use when‚Äù confusion faster than split governance models.

1.2 Security and permissions must remain ‚Äúin the room‚Äù forever

Joule experiences depend on correct setup and permissions. As a result, security changes can ‚Äúbreak‚Äù AI journeys even when AI itself is fine.

Concrete example of impact (permission drift):

  • You enable a manager-facing journey that relies on viewing team data.
  • Security/HR later tightens RBP visibility.
  • Result: managers hit errors or incomplete answers and conclude: ‚ÄúAI is broken.‚Äù

Prevention checklist

  • [ ] Security/Privacy has a permanent seat in Product Council (Section 3)
  • [ ] Every RBP change includes an AI journey impact assessment
  • [ ] Regression includes your top 10 AI-supported workflows (Section 5)
  • [ ] Support team has a ‚ÄúPermission vs AI‚Äù diagnostic script (Section 6)

1.3 Human-in-the-loop maturity progression

Part 2 made this clear: ‚ÄúAI suggests; humans decide.‚Äù Part 3 operationalizes it with maturity:

  • Level 1 (Basic): Generic disclaimer (‚Äúreview output‚Äù).
  • Level 2 (Functional): Use case‚Äìspecific guidance (e.g., drafting content requires compliance review).
  • Level 3 (Optimized): Contextual guardrails at decision points + manager coaching routines + auditable workflow markers (e.g., ‚ÄúAI assisted‚Äù indicator) for sensitive contexts.

1.4 AI literacy maturity model (EU-aligned, practical globally)

EU AI Act Article 4 expects organizations to take measures to ensure sufficient AI literacy for staff using AI systems. Treat literacy as onboarding + refresh + role-based deepening for high-impact roles.

Level
All employeesManagersHigh-impact roles (Recruiting, ER, Performance)
FoundationWhat AI can/can‚Äôt do; basic safety; where to find help+ HITL responsibilities; escalation paths+ Regulatory context; documentation expectations
PracticedQuarterly tips / refreshersManager community of practiceScenario-based practice
AdvancedSelf-service help centerCoaching othersAudit readiness + policy updates

2) AI COE structure with time allocations (minimum viable)

You don‚Äôt need a giant COE. You need clear accountability.

Role
OwnerTime allocation (guidance)Primary accountability
AI Product OwnerHR/HRIT50‚Äì60% FTEOutcomes, backlog priorities, adoption targets
SuccessFactors Platform OwnerHRIT30‚Äì40% FTEConfiguration, RBP changes, release impact, regression
BTP / Integration OwnerIT20‚Äì30% initially (higher if heavy Joule Studio use)Connectivity, extensibility lifecycle
Security + PrivacyCISO/DPO rep10‚Äì15% FTEPolicy, access risk, compliance sign-offs
Change & Enablement LeadHR Comms/L&D30‚Äì40% FTEComms, manager readiness, AI literacy plan
AI Knowledge/Content CuratorCOE/Ops20‚Äì30% FTEApproved sources, quality loop fixes
Adoption & Insights AnalystHRIT/HR Analytics20‚Äì25% FTEDashboards, ticket deflection, failure analysis

Sizing guidance (practical)

  • Small (<5,000 employees): combine roles; ~2 FTE total
  • Medium (5,000‚Äì25,000): ~3.5‚Äì5 FTE
  • Large (25,000+): ~5‚Äì8 FTE initially; higher at maturity depending on custom agents scope

3) Governance cadence with agendas (make it boring and repeatable)

Tier A ‚Äî Executive Steering (Monthly/Quarterly)

Duration: 60 minutes

Standard agenda

  1. Adoption dashboard review (15 min)
  2. Risk register + top 3 issues (15 min)
  3. AI Units consumption vs budget (10 min)
  4. Value delivered vs business case (15 min)
  5. Go/no-go decisions (5 min)

Tier B ‚Äî AI Product Council (Biweekly, 60 min)

Standard agenda

  1. Usage trends + top issues from last sprint (15 min)
  2. Intake review: new requests + prioritization (20 min)
  3. In-flight initiatives: status + blockers (15 min)
  4. Next cycle planning: what goes live (10 min)

Decision aids

  • Prioritization scorecard (Section 4.2)
  • Quality loop summary (Section 6)
  • Capacity planning + AI Units budget view

Tier C ‚Äî AI Ops Review (Weekly, 30 min)

Standard agenda

  1. Hot issues from last 7 days (10 min)
  2. Quality loop: top 5 feedback themes (10 min)
  3. Quick wins for this week (5 min)
  4. Escalations + handoffs (5 min)

Practical embedding of managers

  • Rotate 2‚Äì3 manager representatives through Product Council quarterly
  • Monthly ‚Äúmanager listening sessions‚Äù (30 min) to capture friction
  • Include manager feedback scores in Tier A dashboard

4) Intake and prioritization (stop ‚Äúrandom cool ideas‚Äù)

4.1 Single intake form (required fields)

  • Persona + workflow
  • Value hypothesis + metric
  • Data sensitivity
  • Human-in-the-loop requirement (yes/no + why)
  • Operational cost (support impact)
  • AI Units estimate + monitoring plan

4.2 Prioritization scorecard (weighted, transparent)

Dimension
12345Weight
Business valueMinimal impactNice-to-haveClear benefitHigh valueStrategic3x
FrequencyQuarterlyMonthlyWeeklyDailyMultiple/day2x
ReadinessMajor gapsSome gapsMostly readyReadyPlug-and-play2x
Risk/ComplianceHigh riskModerateStandardLowMinimal-2x
Consumption/CostVery highHighModerateLowMinimal-1x

Priority score formula

Priority Score = [(Value √ó 3) + (Frequency √ó 2) + (Readiness √ó 2)] - [(Risk √ó 2) + (Cost √ó 1)]
Maximum possible: 35
Minimum possible: -15

Prioritization thresholds

  • 25+ = Fast track (next sprint)
  • 15‚Äì24 = Standard backlog (sequence by strategic fit)
  • 10‚Äì14 = Consider (needs strengthening or cost reduction)
  • <10 = Defer or redesign

4.3 Intake decision tree (edge cases)

NEW REQUEST RECEIVED
‚îÇ
‚îú‚îÄ Is this employment-related (recruiting, performance decisions, termination)?
‚îÇ  ‚îú‚îÄ YES ‚Üí Risk = 4 or 5 + Security/Privacy review required
‚îÇ  ‚îî‚îÄ NO ‚Üí Continue
‚îÇ
‚îú‚îÄ Do we have 3+ similar requests from different teams?
‚îÇ  ‚îú‚îÄ YES ‚Üí Consolidate into one initiative (avoid duplication)
‚îÇ  ‚îî‚îÄ NO ‚Üí Continue
‚îÇ
‚îú‚îÄ Does this require NEW data sources or integrations?
‚îÇ  ‚îú‚îÄ YES ‚Üí IT/BTP Owner assesses feasibility first (may delay 1‚Äì2 sprints)
‚îÇ  ‚îî‚îÄ NO ‚Üí Continue
‚îÇ
‚îú‚îÄ Is estimated AI Units cost >20% of monthly budget?
‚îÇ  ‚îú‚îÄ YES ‚Üí Requires Tier A approval before piloting
‚îÇ  ‚îî‚îÄ NO ‚Üí Product Council can approve
‚îÇ
‚îî‚îÄ OUTCOME: Score using Section 4.2 + add to backlog with priority band

5) Release alignment playbook (SuccessFactors + AI)

Treat each SuccessFactors release as an AI change event: permissions/config shifts can break journeys, embedded behaviors can change, and custom agents need regression.

5.1 Release impact example (illustrative)

If permissions for a manager process change but your regression doesn‚Äôt include ‚ÄúJoule + that process,‚Äù you can generate a wave of tickets and a trust hit that takes weeks to recover.

5.2 Minimum release checklist (copy/paste)

  • Preview: identify impacted AI journeys; regression (top workflows + custom agents); refresh enablement (‚Äúwhat changed‚Äù + safe scope)
  • Go-live + 2 weeks: daily monitoring (tickets + wrong/confusing themes); rapid fixes (content, guidance, permissions); escalate defects to SAP if needed
  • Post-release: reprioritize backlog; update manager starter tasks (Part 2) with new value

6) The quality loop (how you reduce wrong/confusing outputs over time)

The goal is not perfection on day one. The goal is a repeatable improvement mechanism.

6.1 Weekly loop: Capture ‚Üí Classify ‚Üí Fix ‚Üí Validate

Step 2: CLASSIFY (weekly)

Issue type
DescriptionExampleTypical fix
A) Missing/unclear contentPolicy/process info missing or outdated‚ÄúCan‚Äôt find updated parental leave policy‚ÄùUpdate knowledge source
B) Permission boundaryUser expects access they don‚Äôt have‚ÄúManager tries to view data outside role‚ÄùFix RBP OR clarify guidance
C) Low confidence/misinterpretationWrong/unclear response‚ÄúMisread internal acronym‚ÄùAdd clarifying content; narrow scope
D) Product defectPlatform behavior/error‚ÄúError with valid permission‚ÄùEscalate to SAP support
E) Misuse/unrealistic expectationUser asks AI to do unsafe things‚ÄúDraft termination letter‚ÄùStrengthen guardrails + enablement

6.3 Example quality improvement (before & after)

Scenario: Joule helps users find learning opportunities.

  • Before: results too broad; users say ‚Äúnot helpful.‚Äù
  • Actions: improve learning paths content + add guidance on better phrasing + apply scope rules.
  • After: users find relevant results faster; repeat usage rises; you scale with updated guidance.

7) AI Units governance (prevent budget surprises)

SAP provides AI Units usage metrics and consumption summaries so you can operationalize consumption governance. You should monitor consumption alongside adoption and value.

7.1 Minimum controls

  • Assign an AI Consumption Owner
  • Monthly consumption review: actual vs planned, spikes by cohort/process, 90-day forecast and guardrails
  • Scaling rule: no new cohort expansion until consumption trend is stable (or budget approved)

7.2 Monthly dashboard (Consumption + Value together)

Track consumption next to value so finance doesn‚Äôt only see ‚Äúcost,‚Äù and HR doesn‚Äôt only see ‚Äúadoption.‚Äù

Metric
This monthLast month3-mo avgTarget
AI Units consumed[_____][_____][_____][_____]
Cost per active user[_____][_____][_____][_____]
Tickets deflected[_____][_____][_____][_____]
Ticket deflection value*[_____][_____][_____][_____]
Net value (deflection ‚àí AI cost)[_____][_____][_____][_____]

*Use your internal cost-per-ticket assumption (e.g., service desk fully loaded cost).

7.3 Consumption spike diagnostic (runbook)

SPIKE DETECTED (>20% month-over-month)
‚îÇ
‚îú‚îÄ New cohort added this month?
‚îÇ  ‚îú‚îÄ YES ‚Üí Expected. Monitor for next 30 days for stabilization.
‚îÇ  ‚îî‚îÄ NO ‚Üí Investigate further ‚Üì
‚îÇ
‚îú‚îÄ New use case launched?
‚îÇ  ‚îú‚îÄ YES ‚Üí Check if usage is appropriate. May need guardrails.
‚îÇ  ‚îî‚îÄ NO ‚Üí Investigate further ‚Üì
‚îÇ
‚îú‚îÄ Seasonal pattern (e.g., year-end reviews, open enrollment)?
‚îÇ  ‚îú‚îÄ YES ‚Üí Expected. Plan for next year.
‚îÇ  ‚îî‚îÄ NO ‚Üí Investigate further ‚Üì
‚îÇ
‚îú‚îÄ Heavy user outliers (top 10% using >5x average)?
‚îÇ  ‚îú‚îÄ YES ‚Üí Interview users:
‚îÇ  ‚îÇ     ‚Ä¢ High-value power users? ‚Üí Good. Feature in case study.
‚îÇ  ‚îÇ     ‚Ä¢ Misuse or bot-like behavior? ‚Üí Restrict or re-train.
‚îÇ  ‚îî‚îÄ NO ‚Üí Escalate to SAP (possible platform anomaly)

Compliance layer (EU focus, strong practice globally)

8.1 AI literacy (Article 4) must be a run-state deliverable

Treat literacy as onboarding + refresh + role-based deepening for high-impact roles. Integrate it into existing learning journeys (e.g., new manager onboarding) rather than creating isolated ‚ÄúAI training.‚Äù

Audience 
Initial (onboarding)Ongoing (run-state)High-impact (annual+)
All employees15-min module: what AI can/can‚Äôt do; where to find it; basic safetyQuarterly tips + refresh for new featuresSelf-service help center
All managers+ 30-min module: HITL responsibilities; escalation; ‚ÄúAI suggests; humans decide‚ÄùManager community of practice (quarterly)Scenario-based refresher
High-impact roles
(Recruiting, Performance, ER)		+ 60-min module: regulatory context; documentation expectations; bias awarenessQuarterly scenario practice + policy updatesAudit readiness workshop

8.2 Employment-related AI use cases require special handling

Maintain an AI Use Case Register for employment/worker-management contexts: classification, controls (HITL, documentation), sign-offs, and change history.

9) Measurement: ATVS dashboard (Adoption, Trust, Value, Safety)

Adoption

  • Active users (7/30)
  • Repeat usage trend

Trust

  • ‚ÄúI understand what‚Äôs safe‚Äù
  • ‚ÄúI know how to escalate‚Äù

Value

  • Ticket deflection
  • Time-to-complete improvements for top HR tasks

Safety

  • Permission boundary incidents
  • Register coverage for employment-related use cases

10) Visual framework: how it all connects

INTAKE ‚Üí PRIORITIZE ‚Üí PILOT ‚Üí QUALITY LOOP ‚Üí SCALE
   ‚Üì          ‚Üì          ‚Üì          ‚Üì           ‚Üì
Product    Tier B     Tier C      Weekly     Tier A
Council   Decision    Review      Ops        Approval
   ‚Üë          ‚Üë          ‚Üë          ‚Üë           ‚Üë
   ‚îî‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚î¥‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚î¥‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚î¥‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îò
              GOVERNANCE CADENCE
                     ‚Üï
           RELEASE ALIGNMENT (each release)
                     ‚Üï
         MEASUREMENT (ATVS Dashboard)

Key dependencies

  • Security/Privacy sits across governance tiers
  • AI Units monitored at Tier C, reviewed at Tier B, and steered/approved at Tier A
  • Quality loop feeds Product Council priorities
  • Release alignment triggers regression testing across all active use cases

11) AI operating model maturity levels

Level 1 ‚Äî Initial (Months 0‚Äì3)

  • Basic COE roles assigned
  • Governance forums established
  • First pilots running
  • Quality loop mostly reactive
  • Ad-hoc consumption monitoring

Level 2 ‚Äî Defined (Months 4‚Äì6)

  • Formal intake process
  • Prioritization scorecard in use
  • Weekly quality loop operational
  • Release regression testing begins
  • Not all use cases have HITL clarity yet

Level 3 ‚Äî Managed (Months 7‚Äì12)

  • Predictable consumption forecasting
  • Value metrics tracked consistently
  • Manager enablement scaled (from Part 2)
  • Proactive quality improvements
  • Release process becomes predictable

Level 4 ‚Äî Optimized (12+ months)

  • AI embedded in HR operating rhythm
  • Self-sustaining quality loop
  • Consumption + value balanced
  • Release process predictable
  • Expanding to new modules confidently

Your practical goal: Reach Level 3 by month 9‚Äì12.

12) Templates (copy/paste)

12.1 COE RACI (starter)

  • AI Product Owner ‚Äî outcomes/backlog/adoption
  • SF Platform Owner ‚Äî configuration/RBP/release regression
  • BTP / Joule Studio Owner ‚Äî custom agent lifecycle
  • Security/Privacy ‚Äî risk acceptance + sign-offs
  • Enablement Lead ‚Äî literacy + communications
  • Knowledge Curator ‚Äî source quality loop fixes
  • Support Lead ‚Äî incident/problem/change coordination

12.2 Intake form (starter)

  • Title + owner
  • Persona + workflow
  • Value metric
  • Safe scope + HITL
  • Data sensitivity
  • AI Units estimate + monitoring plan
  • Pilot cohort
  • Definition of Done

12.3 Release checklist (starter)

  • Review ‚ÄúWhat‚Äôs New‚Äù items impacting Joule/AI journeys
  • Regression: top journeys + custom agents
  • Enablement refresh (what changed + safe scope)
  • Support script update
  • Post-release monitoring plan

Final note

In 2026, the goal isn‚Äôt ‚ÄúAI go-live.‚Äù The goal is habit + trust + measurable value : maintained through an operating rhythm. If you treat AI as a product you operate (intake, backlog, governance, release alignment, quality loop, and ATVS measurement), you significantly increase your chance of scaling impact without losing control of risk or cost.

entry.title: Re: Relational Dataset in Datawarehouse Cloud
entry.content: Just to Add on or I'm just putting it in another way round Relational Dataset is mainly meant to act as a neutral, foundational dataset in SAP Data Warehouse Cloud / Datasphere. You should use a Relational Dataset when you: Are staging or harmonizing data from multiple sources Need to join, filter, or prepare data before deciding KPIs Want a reusable dataset that can later feed Dimensions or Analytical Datasets Do not yet need analytics features like measures, aggregations, hierarchies, or SAC consumption In contrast: Dimension datasets are used for master data, especially when hierarchies, texts, and associations are required. Analytical datasets are required when you want to define measures, aggregation logic, and consume the model directly in SAP Analytics Cloud. So, a good rule of thumb is: If you don‚Äôt need the special features of Dimension or Analytical datasets, use a Relational Dataset as your base model.

entry.content:
Hi All,

SAP Sales Cloud and SAP Service Cloud (C4C) Pre-Release Briefing presentation for the upcoming 2602 (February 2026) release is now available.

We have some key innovations to be shared as part of SAP Sales Cloud and SAP Service Cloud 2602 Release.

Platform & Integration:

Transition Tools:

  • Readiness Check Tool (RCT) | Pre-view showing ABSL code in ‚ÄúPDI Solutions‚Äù tab - The ‚ÄúPDI Solutions‚Äù tab now shows the preview of the ABSL code when you hover on the PDI solution.
  • Data Transfer Tool (DTT) | Additional Objects supporting Transfer - Visits, Route Planning, Account Hierarchy and Surveys are now supported in DTT as transferable objects
  • Data Transfer Tool (DTT) | PDI field data transfer is now available as GA - PDI field data transfer is now available as GA (not a BETA feature anymore)
  • Data Transfer Tool (DTT) | Transfer History extended to show different Transfer Types - Transfer History now reflects additional transfer types like Test Data Transfer, Extension field definition transfer, Business Configuration transfer etc.

PDI:

SAP Cloud Applications Studio installation process - Important Reminder

As you are aware and it was announced in SAP Sales Cloud and Service Cloud 2502 release roll out, the SAP Cloud Applications Studio installation process changed effective August 2025.  As of 2511 (November 2025) release Patch Version 1, SAP Cloud Applications Studio Extension supports devices running on ARM-based processors. The details are available in the SAP online help documentation link.

SAP Cloud Applications Studio (Pilot) will not be supported completely from 2605 release (May 2026). Please plan the migration if it is not done already.

SAP Sales Cloud:

  • Opportunity Management | Search for Opportunities using Product IDs in advanced search - Sales reps can now search for opportunities based on product IDs using the advanced find form without having to launch the filter conditions
  • ISE | Target Plans | Mass Upload Targets - Import targets via mass upload from target console:
    • Export a template pre-filled with selected sales unit or territory hierarchy nodes
    • Prepare or adjust targets offline in Excel or CSV format
    • Upload all targets in a single action

Thanks,

SAP Sales Cloud & SAP Service Cloud Product Management Team
