entry.title: Re: Business Context to Outgoing Checks (FIN_FO_PAYM_CHEC...
entry.content:
Dear @brunobrito2,

In Public Cloud this is expected behavior for Outgoing Checks:

  • The check output you reference (Form: FIN_FO_PAYM_CHECK_US, Data Source: FDP_FFO_PAYM_CHECK_SRV) is not released for key-user extensibility in the way other output forms are. In particular the underlying FDP data source is not available for extension, so you won‚Äôt get a Business Context for it in Custom Fields and Logic

SAP Community below:

https://community.sap.com/t5/enterprise-resource-planning-q-a/payment-voucher-with-check-in-manage-outgoing-checks-s-4hc/qaq-p/12711199

  • SAP also documents for this check form that there is no extensibility logic / master form override available (example shown for address determination), which aligns with the absence of Custom Logic hooks for the form generation

SAP Note below:

https://userapps.support.sap.com/sap/support/knowledge/en/3654275

As a result you cannot add new custom fields (YY1*/ZZ*) to the Outgoing Check form data model via Custom Fields nor populate them via Custom Logic for this specific scenario

Supported/proposal options

Option A: Change the check layout but only with existing fields

You can adjust the form layout by creating your own template and assigning it in Output Management but you‚Äôre still limited to fields that already exist in the delivered data model

High-level steps:

  1. Maintain Form Templates  app download the delivered template adjust it externally, upload as a Z* template
  2. Output Parameter Determination app, show Rules for = Outgoing Check, Determination Step Form Template, assign your Z* template for output type CHECK

 

This is the standard way SAP positions outgoing-check form configuration

IMPORTANT: This does not enable adding new custom fields to the form payload

More details below:

https://help.sap.com/docs/SAP_S4HANA_CLOUD/031c345485b84c8c94265be9ef61d3a8/ecdfbb2e23c24b53a74e03d1ecb07602.html

Option B: Put the extra information on a different, extensible output

If the business requirement is the recipient must see these extra fields the usual clean approach in Public Cloud is to output them on Payment Advice or a similar extensible payment document because SAP explicitly supports adding custom fields there

More details below:

https://help.sap.com/docs/SAP_S4HANA_CLOUD/031c345485b84c8c94265be9ef61d3a8/50d73483ee7b4b2a9bf974113cf51ead.html

Option C: Use an existing standard field that already prints on the check (workaround)

If the requirement is strictly must appear on the check face, you usually have to map the value into a standard field that:

  • is already available in the check data source and
  • is already printed or can be printed on the form for example, reference / note / text fields that are part of the payment or line item context

This is a business workaround, but it is often the only in-system option when the check payload is not extensible

SAP Community below:

https://community.sap.com/t5/enterprise-resource-planning-q-a/payment-voucher-with-check-in-manage-outgoing-checks-s-4hc/qaq-p/12711199

Best Regards,

Dawid

entry.title: SAP Functional Consultants (OTC, P2P, etc.) in the Era of AI Agents - Things might change...
entry.content:
Traditional Functional Testing in SAP

SAP Functional Consultants (in areas like Order-to-Cash (OTC) or Procure-to-Pay (P2P)) have historically focused on configuring business processes and validating them via SAP‚Äôs user interfaces (SAP GUI or Fiori apps). Testing of integrated business processes was largely manual and deterministic ‚Äì for a given input and configuration, the expected output was known. Common practices included:

  • Manual Process Execution: Executing transactions step-by-step in SAP (e.g. creating a Sales Order or Purchase Order) and verifying the outcome on the UI.
  • Using Transaction WE19 for IDocs: If a process involved EDI messages or IDocs, consultants might use WE19 (IDoc test tool) to simulate inbound or outbound IDoc processing. This allowed testing of interfaces that start with an IDoc, but only for classic EDI scenarios.
  • Relying on Integration Teams: For more complex integrations (like web services or APIs), functional consultants often depended on technical teams or waited for external partners to send test messages. Without specialized tools, they had no easy way to simulate those external calls themselves. As a result, testing cycles could be slow and dependent on others. Functional consultants typically viewed advanced automation tools as out-of-scope or overly technical ‚Äì treating them ‚Äúlike mythical dragons, complicated, dangerous, and likely to drag them away from their real work‚Äù. This mindset led to minimal adoption of test automation by functional teams, keeping many tests manual and time-consuming.

The Shift to Integrated and AI-Driven Processes

Today‚Äôs SAP landscapes are increasingly integrated and intelligent. Several trends are transforming how business processes run and, consequently, how they must be tested:

  • Proliferation of APIs and Services: Many business processes now involve web services, REST/OData APIs, and cloud integrations (SAP Integration Suite). For example, an order might be created via an e-commerce API call, or a procurement process might involve a cloud portal sending data into S/4HANA via OData. These are not easily simulated with old tools like WE19 (which only works for IDocs).
  • Event-Driven and Cross-System Flows: End-to-end processes span multiple systems (SAP and non-SAP). A single workflow (e.g. Order-to-Cash) might trigger events in warehouses, tax portals, banks, or partner systems. Testing such flows (using for example SAP Advanced Event Mesh technologies) means ensuring each interface and handoff works ‚Äì something beyond the scope of a single SAP GUI transaction.
  • Introduction of SAP AI Agents (e.g. SAP Joule): SAP is embedding Agentic AI into its applications. Agents like SAP Joule can autonomously perform tasks when given a goal or input (for instance, reading an incoming email with a purchase order PDF and then creating a Sales Order, Delivery, and Invoice in S/4HANA without human clicks). Instead of a user navigating SAP screens, the AI agent orchestrates the process. This is powerful, but it changes the nature of testing: you may need to test the agent‚Äôs behavior and the end results, rather than a user interface.

These changes bring a major challenge: the ‚Äúdeath of determinism‚Äù in testing. With static workflows, one could predict ‚ÄúInput X via transaction Y will produce output Z‚Äù every time. An AI-driven process, however, might not follow the exact same path each run ‚Äì the agent could take different actions or sequence of steps to achieve the same goal, and in worst cases might even ‚Äúhallucinate‚Äù successes. For example, the agent might respond, ‚ÄúOrder created successfully!‚Äù

Figure 1 ‚Äì Order created ‚Äì assuming you trust me

with a polite confirmation, but due to a hidden error (like a mis-mapped field), the order was never actually saved in the database. Traditional test cases that expect a fixed outcome can miss such issues, creating a verification gap where the system‚Äôs UI or the agent‚Äôs message says everything is fine while the database tells another story. In short, just because the AI agent says it did something, doesn‚Äôt guarantee the SAP system state changed accordingly.

Why Traditional Testing Methods Fall Short

Given the above shifts, the old ways of testing have clear limitations:

  • Inability to Simulate New Triggers: Tools like WE19 work for IDoc-based interfaces, but many modern processes begin with different triggers (HTTP calls, cloud events, emails to AI agents). Without the ability to simulate these, functional consultants cannot fully test the process on their own. For example, you can‚Äôt use WE19 to simulate a REST API call or an incoming email ‚Äì you‚Äôd need a tool or script to mimic those external inputs.
  • Manual UI Testing Doesn‚Äôt Cover Backend Integration: A consultant testing via SAP GUI might verify that if they manually create an order, the subsequent IDoc or output is correct. But what if the order is created by an AI agent or an external system call? You‚Äôd have to initiate that external trigger and then verify the outcome inside SAP. Manually, this is cumbersome ‚Äì it might involve sending a request via an API client (like Postman) or waiting for the AI to act, then checking multiple SAP tables or transactions to ensure everything posted correctly. This goes beyond the traditional comfort zone of many functional testers.
  • Non-Deterministic AI Behavior: As mentioned, an AI agent may not behave exactly the same way each time. Traditional test scripts that expect step-by-step consistency may fail even though the end result is acceptable, or worse, may pass a conversational check while missing a functional failure. Most AI governance tools on the market (so-called ‚Äúguardrail‚Äù platforms) focus on prompt safety, security, and compliance ‚Äì ensuring the AI doesn‚Äôt produce toxic output or leak data. They usually do not validate functional integrity of what the AI did. In other words, they watch what the agent says or intends (the tool calls), but not what actually happened in SAP S/4HANA system. If an AI agent politely confirms an action that failed in the backend, a guardrail or conversation test won‚Äôt catch that. This is a huge blind spot for enterprise scenarios.

In summary, the combination of more complex integration points and AI-driven logic means traditional, manual testing by clicking through SAP or using limited tools is no longer sufficient. Organizations risk missing critical issues if they don‚Äôt adopt new testing approaches. The question is: how will the SAP functional consultant‚Äôs role evolve to address this?

Evolving Role of the Functional Consultant: From GUI Tester to End-to-End Process Validator/Guardian 

Moving forward, SAP functional consultants in OTC, P2P, and other domains will likely see their responsibilities broaden. They will still configure business processes, but they will also need to ensure those processes work across system boundaries and with AI in the loop. Key aspects of this evolution include:

  • Testing Beyond the SAP GUI: Consultants will spend less time on purely manual UI testing and more on end-to-end scenario testing. For an order process, this might mean triggering the process the same way it would happen in real life (e.g. via an incoming EDI message, an API call, or an AI agent prompt) and then verifying the results across the system. The focus shifts from ‚ÄúDid the screen show the right data?‚Äù to ‚ÄúDid the entire workflow execute correctly in the backend systems?‚Äù.
  • Becoming API & Integration Savvy: While they may not become full developers, functional consultants will need a working understanding of how to simulate or call APIs, web services, and other integration points. For instance, a P2P consultant might use a tool to send a test JSON payload to an OData service that creates a vendor invoice, then check if the invoice posted and the approval workflow started. In essence, they take on some duties of an API tester, validating that the service calls and data mappings yield the expected results in SAP. This skillset ensures that even if a process is initiated outside of SAP, the consultant can still test it end-to-end.
  • Validating AI Agent Outcomes: As AI agents (like SAP Joule) handle tasks that consultants used to do via the UI, consultants will act as quality guardians for these agents. They might orchestrate test ‚Äúconversations‚Äù or inputs for the agent and then verify the outcomes. For example, an OTC consultant may provide a test email (with an order PDF) to the SAP Joule agent and then confirm that: a Sales Order was created with correct data, a Delivery was generated, and an Invoice posted ‚Äì all according to the business rules. Rather than checking a UI, they‚Äôll check SAP backend records, document flow, or even database entries to ensure the agent‚Äôs actions are functionally correct. In other words, the consultant becomes a "human in the loop" for AI validation, focusing on what the AI did in the system rather than what the AI said.
  • Defining Success Criteria for Probabilistic Processes: In deterministic testing, success is binary (the output matches expected or not). With AI and complex integrations, success may need to be defined in terms of acceptable outcomes or system states. Functional consultants will be instrumental in defining test case expectations for AI-driven processes: e.g., ‚ÄúAn order should be created with the correct customer and items, the tax should be calculated as per configuration, and no error IDocs should result.‚Äù They will design test cases that verify these conditions, even if the exact path the AI agent took (which transactions, what sequence) is not pre-scripted. This is sometimes referred to as a Functional Workflow Execution (FWE) validation ‚Äì ensuring the workflow‚Äôs end results meet functional requirements, regardless of how the agent executed it.
  • Collaboration with Technical Teams: As their role expands into what was traditionally technical testing, functional consultants will likely work more closely with integration experts, BASIS, and QA automation engineers. They‚Äôll need to understand logs, interface monitors, and possibly AI logs to troubleshoot when a test fails. However, rather than waiting for those teams to do the tests, the consultant will be empowered to run many tests themselves, escalating to experts only when something truly goes wrong at a technical level. This collaboration ensures that business process knowledge (which the functional consultant has) is combined with technical validation ‚Äì a necessity for complex scenarios.

In essence, functional consultants are becoming end-to-end business process testers, ensuring that ‚Äúif X leaves SAP or comes into SAP, it is exactly what the outside world expects,‚Äù even when X is triggered by an AI or external system. They will adopt some of the mindset and tools of AI testers and API testers, but with a focus on business correctness and usability rather than pure technical details.

The Role of Specialized Testing Tools (Int4 Suite and Similar)

Crucially, this evolution doesn‚Äôt mean every functional consultant must learn programming or become an automation engineer. New smart testing tools are emerging to bridge the gap, allowing functional consultants to test complex scenarios with minimal coding. One example is Int4 Suite, which has been highlighted as an ‚Äúenterprise AI validator‚Äù or ‚Äúsecret shopper‚Äù for SAP processes. Tools like Int4 Suite offer features that directly address the needs we discussed:

  • Simulation of External Systems (Service Virtualization): Int4 Suite provides simulation agents that can stand in for external partners or systems during testing. For instance, a consultant can simulate an EDI partner sending an ORDERS message or a third-party warehouse sending a confirmation, without waiting for the real system. The tool leverages real production data ‚Äì consultants can select actual historical messages (IDocs, API payloads, etc.) and replay them in the test environment on-demand. This means even if a process normally begins outside SAP, the functional tester can trigger it at will. It works for both EDI/IDoc and non-EDI (API/web service) interactions.
  • Simple Interface, No Coding Required: Instead of forcing consultants to write scripts or learn complex test frameworks, the tool presents a user-friendly interface (e.g., pick a historical message, tweak some values, and send). As one source put it, ‚ÄúThe better path is not to force functional consultants into scripting or automation frameworks, but to give them simulation agents that mimic the system environment‚Äù. This approach avoids a steep learning curve. Consultants can use their SAP process knowledge to choose relevant test cases, and the tool handles the technical message sending and data injection behind the scenes.
  • End-to-End Validation (Deep Backend Checks): A critical feature is automatic result validation. When the consultant triggers a test (whether it‚Äôs creating a doc in SAP or sending an inbound message), Int4 Suite will automatically check the outcomes at a granular level. For example, after an outbound IDoc is generated or an API call is processed, the tool compares the new output to the expected output (often using the historical production message as the ‚Äúgold standard‚Äù). It can validate that every relevant field matches, that totals are correctly calculated, and even that follow-on documents (like an invoice or accounting document) are created as expected. This is exactly the kind of functional integrity check that would catch an AI agent‚Äôs mistakes ‚Äì if the agent missed a field mapping or made an error, the discrepancy would be flagged when comparing the new system output to the known correct output from a similar past scenario.

 Figure 2 ‚Äì Backend Validation in Int4 Suite

 

  • ‚ÄúSecret Shopper‚Äù Testing for AI Agents: In the context of SAP‚Äôs AI agents, a tool like this can act as a secret shopper ‚Äì essentially a fake customer that tests the agent. For the earlier example of an email-to-order scenario, Int4 Suite can automatically retrieve a real email and PDF order from the company‚Äôs archive, modify certain details to make it a unique test, and send it to the AI agent. Once the AI agent processes it (creating an order, delivery, invoice), Int4 Suite dives into S/4HANA‚Äôs backend to verify each document‚Äôs presence and correctness (e.g., checking that net value, tax, shipping point, etc., match the expected outcome). This way, the agent‚Äôs entire end-to-end functionality is validated, not just the message it returned in the chat. If something failed (like the agent said ‚Äúorder created‚Äù but no order exists, or the invoice values are wrong), the tool will catch it immediately.

 

Figure 3 ‚Äì secret shopper figure

  • Use of Historical Data and Dynamic Data Fabrication: Because these tools often integrate with SAP directly, they can pull realistic test data. Int4 Suite‚Äôs approach is to use a ‚Äúrobotic crawler‚Äù to fetch historical messages and then dynamically fabricate variants of them for testing. This ensures test scenarios are very close to real business cases (with all the complexity of real data), increasing the chance of catching issues. Consultants can test edge cases (like a huge Black Friday order load, or a partially delivered order response) by simply replaying those real scenarios in a controlled way. This capability is far more powerful than hand-crafting test data in a spreadsheet.

By equipping functional consultants with such simulation and validation agents, organizations get several benefits: ‚ÄúTest cycles shorten dramatically, reliance on external partners and scarce integration resources drops, and confidence in end-to-end quality rises.‚Äù In other words, a tool like Int4 Suite transforms the functional consultant into a self-sufficient end-to-end tester, without turning them into programmers. They can rapidly run through many integrated scenarios on their own, as frequently as needed, which is essential in an AI-driven, non-deterministic world. It fills in the missing piece of testing by confirming that what leaves or enters SAP in these integrated processes is correct to the last field.

Possible Adaptation Strategies for Consultants

The transition to this new reality won‚Äôt happen overnight for everyone. Different organizations and individuals might take different approaches as these changes loom:

  • Full Embrace of the New Role: Many functional consultants (or entire teams) will fully embrace the role of AI/API-enabled process testers. They will upskill on using tools like Int4 Suite or other SAP testing frameworks and become comfortable simulating APIs and AI-driven scenarios. In this mode, a consultant effectively becomes a hybrid of a functional expert and an integration tester. They design test cases, use simulation tools to execute them, and interpret the results. This path ensures they remain highly relevant and valuable, as they can guarantee that business processes work correctly across all layers. It does require learning new tools and thinking beyond just SAP‚Äôs UI, but the payoff is a much faster and more reliable testing cycle ‚Äì and fewer production surprises. (This is the ‚Äúyes in all of those‚Äù changes scenario ‚Äì taking on AI testing, API testing, and new tools altogether.)
  • Remain SAP-Centric (Traditionalist Approach): Some may choose (or initially attempt) to stick narrowly to classic SAP customization and UI testing, leaving the AI and integration aspects to specialized testers or developers. For instance, a consultant might test only the SAP transaction portions and assume that the integration team will ensure external inputs/outputs are correct. This ‚Äújust SAP‚Äù approach might feel comfortable, but it has risks. It can create bottlenecks (always waiting on someone else for the end-to-end test) and blind spots (the consultant might miss how a configuration change impacts the API or agent behavior). In the long run, as SAP agents and integrations become core to processes, a consultant who doesn‚Äôt engage with those aspects could find their testing incomplete or their role limited. This option might work in the short term in organizations where roles are strictly separated, but it‚Äôs likely not sustainable as the norm shifts toward cross-functional testing skills.
  • Partial or Gradual Adoption: A middle path is to incrementally adopt these new responsibilities. Consultants might start by learning to use one simulation tool for a specific pain point (say, simulating an EDI partner message) while still doing other tests manually. Or they might pair up with integration engineers for a while ‚Äì the consultant defines the business scenarios and expected results, and the engineer helps set up the API calls or agent triggers. Over time, the consultant picks up more of the skills and tools. In this ‚Äúyes, but not too much‚Äù scenario, they do expand their role, but carefully and not all at once. This can be practical for teams that need to maintain current projects while gradually modernizing their testing approach. The key is that even partial adoption of tools like Int4 Suite can yield significant improvements (for example, using it just to simulate inbound messages can save a lot of time). Eventually, as confidence and competence grow, consultants can take on more.
  • New Specialist Roles Emerge: It‚Äôs also possible that entirely new roles or job titles will appear ‚Äì for example, ‚ÄúSAP AI Process Tester‚Äù or ‚ÄúEnterprise AI Validation Engineer.‚Äù These could be professionals who bridge the gap between functional knowledge and AI technical know-how. Experienced functional consultants might transition into such roles, or they might work alongside them. In either case, the existence of such roles underlines that testing integrated, AI-infused processes is a specialty of its own. Consultants should be prepared to collaborate with these specialists or become one themselves. What‚Äôs likely, however, is that even if dedicated AI testers exist, the functional consultant will still need to closely cooperate and provide business context ‚Äì so some level of understanding of the new testing paradigms is necessary.

Regardless of the approach, one thing is clear: the need for robust testing of end-to-end processes (including AI actions) is only going to increase. SAP functional consultants are in a prime position to take up that challenge, given their deep understanding of business rules and process outcomes. They will not necessarily code test scripts from scratch, but they will orchestrate and validate tests using new-generation tools. As the enterprise software world embraces ‚Äúprobabilistic‚Äù AI agents and highly API-driven architectures, the consultant‚Äôs role evolves from simply configuring and eyeballing the result on a screen, to actively safeguarding the integrity of complex, automated workflows.

Preparing for the Future

For SAP functional consultants wondering how to stay ahead in this changing landscape, here are a few final thoughts:

  • Get Familiar with Integration Technologies: You don‚Äôt need to be a developer, but learn the basics of how data enters/exits SAP in your domain (OData services, IDoc flows, BAPIs, etc.). Understand the tools available (e.g., SAP API Hub, Int4 Suite, or SAP‚Äôs own testing utilities) to send or monitor those interfaces.
  • Experiment with AI (in a Safe Environment): If your organization is introducing SAP AI agents like Joule, try to get involved in the early testing. Ask to be part of the pilot. Treat it as an opportunity to build ‚ÄúAI literacy‚Äù ‚Äì learn how the agent is supposed to operate, what data it uses, and how to trigger it. Maybe set up a sandbox where you can play with the agent‚Äôs skills without risk.
  • Leverage Test Automation Tools Designed for SAP: Tools such as Int4 Suite (and others in the SAP ecosystem) are there to help. They are built with SAP processes in mind (understanding IDocs, BAPIs, document flows) which generic testing tools might not easily handle. Investing time to learn one of these tools can pay off greatly. As we saw, providing simulation agents to consultants can change the game by eliminating dependencies and speeding up tests. It‚Äôs worth advocating within your project to bring in such tools ‚Äì not just for AI, but for any integrated process testing.
  • Mindset Shift ‚Äì From Tester to Guardian of the Process: Finally, embrace a mindset change. Instead of seeing testing as a step where you click through a script to confirm your configuration works, view yourself as the guardian of the end-to-end process. Your goal is to ensure that when all the moving parts (SAP modules, integrations, AI agents, partner systems) play together, the business outcome is correct and reliable. This holistic view will naturally drive you to adopt whatever techniques and tools are needed (be it learning to read a JSON payload or interpreting an AI agent log). It‚Äôs an exciting expansion of the functional consultant‚Äôs role ‚Äì one that can make you even more valuable in an AI-powered enterprise.

Conclusion

Yes, SAP functional consultants will evolve to become more like AI/API testers for their business processes ‚Äì in fact, they will become full-spectrum process validators. They‚Äôll still use their core business knowledge, but augmented with new testing skills and tools. The introduction of AI agents and heavily integrated processes doesn‚Äôt diminish the importance of the functional consultant; on the contrary, it amplifies the need for their insight to ensure these intelligent systems do the right thing. The likely scenario (and in many cases, the only viable one) is that consultants embrace this change: using specialized tools, they will test conversations and API calls with the same comfort as they tested transactions in SAPGUI. This comprehensive approach is what will maintain enterprise-grade trust in an era where software is no longer fully deterministic. By adopting solutions that allow deep backend verification and service virtualization, functional consultants can close the ‚Äúverification gap‚Äù and keep their processes running smoothly.

Further Learning on Int4 Suite 

  • SAP Learning Course: Avoid SAP S/4HANA Project Delays with Third-Party Systems Service Virtualization

entry.title: Re: SAC Data Action rounding differences - how to force 2...
entry.content:
Hi @vinay_009 

There is "ROUND()" function in the Advanced formulas script. You can get your expected result from the script logic with ROUND() function.

In your case, if Price & Quantity and to get the Revenue (Price * Quantity)

  • Price: 132.7628388
  • Quantity: 1,500

 

Without Rounding

  • Calculate Result

  • Advanced Formulas script
DATA([d/Account] = "Revenue") = RESULTLOOKUP([d/Account] = "Price") * RESULTLOOKUP([d/Account] = "Quantity")

 

With Rounding

  • Calculate Result

  • Advanced Formulas script
DATA([d/Account] = "Revenue") = ROUND(RESULTLOOKUP([d/Account] = "Price"), 2) * RESULTLOOKUP([d/Account] = "Quantity")

 I hope this is helpful to you, and if I have misunderstood anything, please feel free to reach out.

Moonjun

entry.title: Re: Unable to Delete Tax Code Rate Due to Posted Documents
entry.content:
Yes ‚Äî the recommendation still applies even though the changes were made only in your Test system and not yet transported to Production.

Here‚Äôs why:

System behavior is the same across environments: The restriction on deleting tax rates once documents exist after the valid‚Äëfrom date is a standard control in SAP S/4HANA Public Cloud. It applies equally in Test, Quality, and Production.

Audit integrity principle: SAP prevents deletion because the tax rate has already been ‚Äúin use‚Äù in posted documents. Reversals don‚Äôt change that fact. This rule is not environment‚Äëspecific.

Transport impact: Since you haven‚Äôt transported the 6% rate to Production yet, you can simply avoid transporting that change. In Production, you can directly maintain the correct validity interval (e.g., keep 6.72% until 19.01.2026, then 6% from 20.01.2026 if that‚Äôs correct). If the TR is not yet released, you can carry out the changes in the same TR
